Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The weaver was skilled at making ____ out of _____.
Options: A. Ropes; light, B. Baskets; bamboo, C. Shirts; silk, D. Robes; clouds
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What special skill did the youngest princess possess in the celestial court of the Jade Emperor? Options: A. She could create beautiful music., B. She could pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into the softest robes., C. She could heal any wound., D. She could communicate with animals. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why did the Queen Mother grant the weaver permission to visit Earth? Options: A. To punish her for being disobedient., B. To allow her to experience new inspiration for her craft., C. To test her loyalty to the celestial court., D. To find a suitable husband for her. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What advice did the bull give to the cowherd when he saw the weaver's beauty? Options: A. To ignore her and focus on his work., B. To approach her and introduce himself confidently., C. To tell him of the swimmer's celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth., D. To warn him of the dangers of loving a celestial being. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the condition for the weaver to remain on Earth? Options: A. She had to marry the cowherd., B. She had to lose her ticket back to Heaven., C. She had to learn to farm and live a simple life., D. She had to forget her celestial origins. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the significance of the bull's hide in the story? Options: A. It was a symbol of the cowherd's wealth., B. It was used to make a magical robe for the weaver., C. It was used to create a bridge between Heaven and Earth., D. It was a source of magic that the family could use in times of need. Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why was the weaver's family enraged when they learned of her new life on Earth? Options: A. They were jealous of her happiness., B. They were angry that she had wasted her love on a human., C. They were worried about her safety., D. They were disappointed that she had abandoned her celestial duties. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the result of the Queen Mother's anger towards the weaver? Options: A. She was banished from the celestial court., B. A great gulf opened, forming a river of stars between Heaven and Earth., C. The weaver was forced to return to her celestial duties., D. The cowherd was punished for loving a celestial being. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What event occurs every year that allows the weaver and the cowherd to reunite? Options: A. The summer solstice., B. The winter solstice., C. The formation of a bridge across the Milky Way by magpies., D. The celestial alignment of the stars. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the cultural significance of the story of the weaver and the cowherd? Options: A. It is a cautionary tale about the dangers of loving someone from a different social class., B. It is a celebration of the power of love to overcome even celestial obstacles., C. It is a reminder of the importance of filial piety., D. It is a mythological explanation for the creation of the Milky Way. Correct Option: None
Question 10: In which regions of the world is the story of the weaver and the cowherd commonly told? Options: A. East and Southeast Asia., B. Europe and North America., C. Africa and South America., D. Australia and Oceania. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although Question 1 does not exactly match the format of the ground truth MCQ, its content and intent are the most similar. The ground truth MCQ asks about the weaver's skill, and Question 1 asks about the youngest princess's (who is the weaver) special skill. The correct answer for Question 1 (B. She could pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into the softest robes.) is equivalent to the correct answer for the ground truth MCQ (D. Robes; clouds).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did the cowherd come to the river to do?
Options: A. Pick grass for his bull, B. Sweep his parents’ graves, C. Swim, D. Read a book
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:

She could pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into the softest robes., C. She could heal any wound., D. She could communicate with animals. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why did the Queen Mother grant the weaver permission to visit Earth? Options: A. To punish her for being disobedient., B. To allow her to experience new inspiration for her craft., C. Question 5: What was the significance of the bull's hide in the story? Options: A. It was a symbol of the cowherd's wealth., B. It was used to make a magical robe for the weaver., C. It was used to create a bridge between Heaven and Earth., D. It was a source of magic that the family could use in times of need. Correct Option: None

Correct Option: None
Question 8: What event occurs every year that allows the weaver and the cowherd to reunite? Options: A. The summer solstice., B. The winter solstice., C. The formation of a bridge across the Milky Way by magpies., D. The celestial alignment of the stars. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the cultural significance of the story of the weaver and the cowherd? Options: A. It is a cautionary tale about the dangers of loving someone from a different social class., B. It is a celebration of the power of love to overcome even celestial obstacles., C. It is a reminder of the importance of filial piety., D. It is a mythological explanation for the creation of the Milky Way. Correct Option: None
Question 10: In which regions of the world is the story of the weaver and the cowherd commonly told? Options: A. East and Southeast Asia., B. Europe and North America., C. Africa and South America., D. Australia and Oceania. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the cowherd's reason for coming to the river, which is to sweep his parents' graves. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 3 mentions the cowherd and his actions near the river.

However, since none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ, I will not provide an index. Instead, I suggest creating a new generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ more closely.

Here's an example of a new generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ:

Question: Why did the cowherd come to the river?
Options: A. To swim, B. To sweep his parents' graves, C. To pick grass for his bull, D. To read a book
Correct Option: B

This new generated MCQ matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did the cowherd use to fly up to heaven?
Options: A. The weaver’s clothing, B. A pair of baskets, C. A flock of birds, D. The bull’s pelt
Correct Option: D

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

Although the question content is not identical, the options provided in Question 5 include the correct answer from the ground truth MCQ (the bull's pelt being a source of magic that the family could use in times of need, specifically for the cowherd to fly up to heaven). The intent of the question is also similar, as it focuses on the significance of the bull's hide in the story, which is closely related to the cowherd's use of the bull's pelt to fly up to heaven.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: By the Queen Mother’s decree, the weaver and cowherd could meet _____.
Options: A. Once a day, B. Once a year, C. Once every 10 years, D. Never
Correct Option: B

It was used to create a bridge between Heaven and Earth., D. It was a source of magic that the family could use in times of need. Correct Option: None

A great gulf opened, forming a river of stars between Heaven and Earth., C. The weaver was forced to return to her celestial duties., D. The cowherd was punished for loving a celestial being. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What event occurs every year that allows the weaver and the cowherd to reunite? Options: A. The summer solstice., B. The winter solstice., C. The formation of a bridge across the Milky Way by magpies., D. The celestial alignment of the stars. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the cultural significance of the story of the weaver and the cowherd? Options: A. It is a cautionary tale about the dangers of loving someone from a different social class., B. It is a celebration of the power of love to overcome even celestial obstacles., C. It is a reminder of the importance of filial piety., D. It is a mythological explanation for the creation of the Milky Way. Correct Option: None
Question 10: In which regions of the world is the story of the weaver and the cowherd commonly told? Options: A. East and Southeast Asia., B. Europe and North America., C. Africa and South America., D. Australia and Oceania. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the event that allows the weaver and the cowherd to reunite. The correct option in Question 8 (C. The formation of a bridge across the Milky Way by magpies) is related to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (B. Once a year), as the formation of the bridge by magpies occurs once a year, allowing the weaver and the cowherd to meet.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which birds help the weaver and cowherd reunite?
Options: A. magpies   , B. swans, C. crows, D. doves
Correct Option: A

Question 2: Why did the Queen Mother grant the weaver permission to visit Earth? Options: A. To punish her for being disobedient., B. To allow her to experience new inspiration for her craft., C. Question 5: What was the significance of the bull's hide in the story? Options: A. It was a symbol of the cowherd's wealth., B. It was used to make a magical robe for the weaver., C. It was used to create a bridge between Heaven and Earth., D. It was a source of magic that the family could use in times of need. Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why was the weaver's family enraged when they learned of her new life on Earth? Options: A. They were jealous of her happiness., B. They were angry that she had wasted her love on a human., C. They were worried about her safety., D. They were disappointed that she had abandoned her celestial duties. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the result of the Queen Mother's anger towards the weaver? Options: A. She was banished from the celestial court., B. A great gulf opened, forming a river of stars between Heaven and Earth., C. The weaver was forced to return to her celestial duties., D. The cowherd was punished for loving a celestial being. Correct Option: None

It is a mythological explanation for the creation of the Milky Way. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As Numberland’s best detective,
you thought you’d seen it all. But the desiccated corpses 
of prominent natural numbers— whole numbers greater than 0— have been showing up all over the city
for the past week. All of Digitopolis is on lockdown
from sundown to sunrise, and it’s still not enough to stop
what can only be described as a vampiric feeding frenzy. The police are helpless, 
and have turned to you. You put the missing persons case 
you’ve been investigating on hold and study the evidence. Here’s what you know: most victims have been completely
drained of their life’s essence. Some have a thin line of slime
separating digits— some of which were drained 
and others spared. Which leads you to mystery one: what’s the significance 
of the slime-lines, and why are certain digits untouched? Pause here to figure it out yourself. 
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s start by looking 
for a pattern in the victims. Why have some been fully drained,
and some slimed? Well, the slime-lined are in their prime— which is to say they’re prime numbers,
divisible only by 1 and themselves. Not a single one of the unslimed numbers,
on the other hand, is. Furthermore, the drained parts of the 
slimed primes are not, themselves, prime. When 71 got slimed, 7 was prime,
but 1 was not. If 461 had been split into 4 and 61,
the right side would have been prime, but instead it was split further
into non-prime digits. And when 2099 got slimed, 
the attacker went with 20 and 99, and was able to drain both. So you have a big problem. There are infinite potential victims: all non-prime numbers, and all prime numbers that can 
be slime-lined to reveal at least one non-prime number. In fact, you can only think of a few
numbers that aren't vulnerable. First of all, the one digit primes: 
2, 3, 5, and 7. Then primes like 23, which could only be
split into 2 and 3, both prime. These numbers are familiar, but why? Aha! Your missing person’s case. Someone is kidnapping the numbers
that can’t be drained: we’ll call them the immune. If you can identify the four immune 
who remain, perhaps you can get to them first
and figure out what’s going on. Who are the immune?
Pause here to figure it out yourself. Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There are 4 one-digit immune:
2, 3, 5, and 7. All have already been kidnapped. But every digit in all of the immune
must be one of those four numbers; otherwise there would be 
a non-prime split possible. That means there are only these 16
candidates among the two-digit numbers. The ones that are prime must be immune. We can eliminate anything 
that ends in 2 or 5, as they’ll always be divisible by 2 and 5. This diagonal is also out,
as they’re divisible by 11. If the digits of a number add
up to a multiple of 3, it’s divisible by 3. So that eliminates 57 and 27,
leaving these numbers. Which, upon double-checking, are, 
in fact, immune. We now have a strong starting point
for searching three-digit numbers: any 2 consecutive digits must be 
on the list of the two-digit immune. Those all end in 3 and 7, so the only possibilities
are these 8 options: the two-digit immune with additional
3s or 7s on their ends. 3 can’t follow 3,
nor 7 follow 7. And once again, adding the digits 
reveals that 237 and 537 are divisible by 3. 737 is 67 times 11, 
so that leaves just 373, which is, in fact, prime,
and therefore immune. Could a four-digit number be immune? No, any consecutive three digits
would have to be immune, and there’s no immune three digit
number that starts with a 7. You rush out, 
but reach each home too late, until the only immune left is 373. You’re in the nick of time to scare
off her would-be kidnapper; not the vampire itself but a minion. 373 explains that she and the other immune
are the subjects of an ancient prophecy that designated them as vampire slayers. They’d sometimes gather and try 
to figure out what a vampire is, but no one had the slightest idea. They found the idea of slaying
things quite distasteful. You both trail her would-be kidnapper
back to a foreboding castle. There you release the other 
kidnapped numbers and confront the vampire himself. He’s powerless before the slayers, 
but ever the pacifists, they round him up, return the lifeforce 
to his victims, and send him packing. Numberland is safe... for now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which one of these statements is true?
Options: A. 1 is a prime number., B. All prime numbers are odd., C. 2, 3, 5, and 7 are the only one-digit primes.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of numbers were the victims that had a thin line of slime separating their digits? Options: A. Even numbers, B. Prime numbers, C. Odd numbers, D. Composite numbers Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why were some digits of the slimed prime numbers left untouched? Options: A. Because they were also prime numbers, B. Because they were even numbers, C. Because they were divisible by 3, D. Because they were greater than 5 Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the characteristic of the "immune" numbers in the story? Options: A. They are all composite numbers, B. They are all prime numbers that cannot be split into non-prime digits, C. They are all even numbers, D. They are all odd numbers Correct Option: None
Question 4: How many one-digit immune numbers are there? Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5 Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the rule for a two-digit number to be immune? Options: A. Both digits must be prime numbers, B. The sum of the digits must be a multiple of 3, C. The number must be divisible by 11, D. The number must end in 2 or 5 Correct Option: None
Question 6: How many two-digit immune numbers are there? Options: A. 4, B. 6, C. 8, D. 16 Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the rule for a three-digit number to be immune? Options: A. Any two consecutive digits must be on the list of two-digit immune numbers, B. The sum of the digits must be a multiple of 3, C. The number must be divisible by 11, D. The number must end in 2 or 5 Correct Option: None
Question 8: How many three-digit immune numbers are there? Options: A. 2, B. 4, C. 6, D. 8 Correct Option: None
Question 9: Can a four-digit number be immune? Options: A. Yes, if it meets the same rules as the three-digit immune numbers, B. No, because any consecutive three digits would have to be immune, C. Yes, if it ends in 2 or 5, D. No, because it would be too large Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the special role of the immune numbers in the story? Options: A. They are the victims of the vampire's attacks, B. They are the vampire's minions, C. They are the vampire slayers, D. They are the detectives trying to solve the mystery Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is:

**Question 4: How many one-digit immune numbers are there? Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5**

Although the question is not an exact match, the content and options are closely related to the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks about the one-digit primes, and the generated MCQ asks about the one-digit immune numbers, which are the same set of numbers (2, 3, 5, and 7) in the context of the story.

The correct option for the generated MCQ is C. 4, which matches the correct option of the ground truth MCQ (C. 2, 3, 5, and 7 are the only one-digit primes).

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is **4**.

As Numberland’s best detective,
you thought you’d seen it all. But the desiccated corpses

separating digits— some of which were drained 
and others spared. Which leads you to mystery one: what’s the significance

for a pattern in the victims. Why have some been fully drained,

and figure out what’s going on. Who are the immune?
Pause here to figure it out yourself. Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There are 4 one-digit immune:
2, 3, 5, and 7. All have already been kidnapped. But every digit in all of the immune
must be one of those four numbers; otherwise there would be 
a non-prime split possible. That means there are only these 16
candidates among the two-digit numbers. The ones that are prime must be immune. We can eliminate anything 
that ends in 2 or 5, as they’ll always be divisible by 2 and 5. This diagonal is also out,

leaving these numbers. Which, upon double-checking, are, 
in fact, immune. We now have a strong starting point
for searching three-digit numbers: any 2 consecutive digits must be 
on the list of the two-digit immune. Those all end in 3 and 7, so the only possibilities
are these 8 options: the two-digit immune with additional
3s or 7s on their ends. 3 can’t follow 3,
nor 7 follow 7. And once again, adding the digits 
reveals that 237 and 537 are divisible by 3. 737 is 67 times 11, 
so that leaves just 373, which is, in fact, prime,
and therefore immune. Could a four-digit number be immune? No, any consecutive three digits
would have to be immune, and there’s no immune three digit
number that starts with a 7. You rush out, 
but reach each home too late, until the only immune left is 373. You’re in the nick of time to scare
off her would-be kidnapper; not the vampire itself but a minion. 373 explains that she and the other immune
are the subjects of an ancient prophecy that designated them as vampire slayers. They’d sometimes gather and try 
to figure out what a vampire is, but no one had the slightest idea. They found the idea of slaying
things quite distasteful. You both trail her would-be kidnapper
back to a foreboding castle. There you release the other 
kidnapped numbers and confront the vampire himself. He’s powerless before the slayers, 
but ever the pacifists, they round him up, return the lifeforce 
to his victims, and send him packing. Numberland is safe... for now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Only prime numbers., B. Only numbers that are not prime., C. A mix of primes and non-primes.
Correct Option: C

Question 2: Why were some digits of the slimed prime numbers left untouched? Options: A. Because they were also prime numbers, B. Because they were even numbers, C. Because they were divisible by 3, D. Because they were greater than 5 Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the characteristic of the "immune" numbers in the story? Options: A. They are all composite numbers, B. They are all prime numbers that cannot be split into non-prime digits, C. They are all even numbers, D. They are all odd numbers Correct Option: None
Question 4: How many one-digit immune numbers are there? Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5 Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the rule for a two-digit number to be immune? Options: A. Both digits must be prime numbers, B. The sum of the digits must be a multiple of 3, C. The number must be divisible by 11, D. The number must end in 2 or 5 Correct Option: None
Question 6: How many two-digit immune numbers are there? Options: A. 4, B. 6, C. 8, D. 16 Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the rule for a three-digit number to be immune? Options: A. Any two consecutive digits must be on the list of two-digit immune numbers, B. The sum of the digits must be a multiple of 3, C. The number must be divisible by 11, D. The number must end in 2 or 5 Correct Option: None
Question 8: How many three-digit immune numbers are there? Options: A. 2, B. 4, C. 6, D. 8 Correct Option: None
Question 9: Can a four-digit number be immune? Options: A. Yes, if it meets the same rules as the three-digit immune numbers, B. No, because any consecutive three digits would have to be immune, C. Yes, if it ends in 2 or 5, D. No, because it would be too large Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the special role of the immune numbers in the story? Options: A. They are the victims of the vampire's attacks, B. They are the vampire's minions, C. They are the vampire slayers, D. They are the detectives trying to solve the mystery Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As Numberland’s best detective,
you thought you’d seen it all. But the desiccated corpses 
of prominent natural numbers— whole numbers greater than 0— have been showing up all over the city
for the past week. All of Digitopolis is on lockdown
from sundown to sunrise, and it’s still not enough to stop
what can only be described as a vampiric feeding frenzy. The police are helpless, 
and have turned to you. You put the missing persons case 
you’ve been investigating on hold and study the evidence. Here’s what you know: most victims have been completely
drained of their life’s essence. Some have a thin line of slime
separating digits— some of which were drained 
and others spared. Which leads you to mystery one: what’s the significance 
of the slime-lines, and why are certain digits untouched? Pause here to figure it out yourself. 
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s start by looking 
for a pattern in the victims. Why have some been fully drained,
and some slimed? Well, the slime-lined are in their prime— which is to say they’re prime numbers,
divisible only by 1 and themselves. Not a single one of the unslimed numbers,
on the other hand, is. Furthermore, the drained parts of the 
slimed primes are not, themselves, prime. When 71 got slimed, 7 was prime,
but 1 was not. If 461 had been split into 4 and 61,
the right side would have been prime, but instead it was split further
into non-prime digits. And when 2099 got slimed, 
the attacker went with 20 and 99, and was able to drain both. So you have a big problem. There are infinite potential victims: all non-prime numbers, and all prime numbers that can 
be slime-lined to reveal at least one non-prime number. In fact, you can only think of a few
numbers that aren't vulnerable. First of all, the one digit primes: 
2, 3, 5, and 7. Then primes like 23, which could only be
split into 2 and 3, both prime. These numbers are familiar, but why? Aha! Your missing person’s case. Someone is kidnapping the numbers
that can’t be drained: we’ll call them the immune. If you can identify the four immune 
who remain, perhaps you can get to them first
and figure out what’s going on. Who are the immune?
Pause here to figure it out yourself. Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There are 4 one-digit immune:
2, 3, 5, and 7. All have already been kidnapped. But every digit in all of the immune
must be one of those four numbers; otherwise there would be 
a non-prime split possible. That means there are only these 16
candidates among the two-digit numbers. The ones that are prime must be immune. We can eliminate anything 
that ends in 2 or 5, as they’ll always be divisible by 2 and 5. This diagonal is also out,
as they’re divisible by 11. If the digits of a number add
up to a multiple of 3, it’s divisible by 3. So that eliminates 57 and 27,
leaving these numbers. Which, upon double-checking, are, 
in fact, immune. We now have a strong starting point
for searching three-digit numbers: any 2 consecutive digits must be 
on the list of the two-digit immune. Those all end in 3 and 7, so the only possibilities
are these 8 options: the two-digit immune with additional
3s or 7s on their ends. 3 can’t follow 3,
nor 7 follow 7. And once again, adding the digits 
reveals that 237 and 537 are divisible by 3. 737 is 67 times 11, 
so that leaves just 373, which is, in fact, prime,
and therefore immune. Could a four-digit number be immune? No, any consecutive three digits
would have to be immune, and there’s no immune three digit
number that starts with a 7. You rush out, 
but reach each home too late, until the only immune left is 373. You’re in the nick of time to scare
off her would-be kidnapper; not the vampire itself but a minion. 373 explains that she and the other immune
are the subjects of an ancient prophecy that designated them as vampire slayers. They’d sometimes gather and try 
to figure out what a vampire is, but no one had the slightest idea. They found the idea of slaying
things quite distasteful. You both trail her would-be kidnapper
back to a foreboding castle. There you release the other 
kidnapped numbers and confront the vampire himself. He’s powerless before the slayers, 
but ever the pacifists, they round him up, return the lifeforce 
to his victims, and send him packing. Numberland is safe... for now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The vampire’s goal with the slime lines is to:
Options: A. Scare his victims., B. Isolate prime sequences in order to drain them., C. Isolate non-prime sequences in order to drain them.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of numbers were the victims that had a thin line of slime separating their digits? Options: A. Even numbers, B. Prime numbers, C. Odd numbers, D. Composite numbers Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why were some digits of the slimed prime numbers left untouched? Options: A. Because they were also prime numbers, B. Because they were even numbers, C. Because they were divisible by 3, D. Because they were greater than 5 Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the characteristic of the "immune" numbers in the story? Options: A. They are all composite numbers, B. They are all prime numbers that cannot be split into non-prime digits, C. They are all even numbers, D. They are all odd numbers Correct Option: None
Question 4: How many one-digit immune numbers are there? Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5 Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the rule for a two-digit number to be immune? Options: A. Both digits must be prime numbers, B. The sum of the digits must be a multiple of 3, C. The number must be divisible by 11, D. The number must end in 2 or 5 Correct Option: None
Question 6: How many two-digit immune numbers are there? Options: A. 4, B. 6, C. 8, D. 16 Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the rule for a three-digit number to be immune? Options: A. Any two consecutive digits must be on the list of two-digit immune numbers, B. The sum of the digits must be a multiple of 3, C. The number must be divisible by 11, D. The number must end in 2 or 5 Correct Option: None
Question 8: How many three-digit immune numbers are there? Options: A. 2, B. 4, C. 6, D. 8 Correct Option: None
Question 9: Can a four-digit number be immune? Options: A. Yes, if it meets the same rules as the three-digit immune numbers, B. No, because any consecutive three digits would have to be immune, C. Yes, if it ends in 2 or 5, D. No, because it would be too large Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the special role of the immune numbers in the story? Options: A. They are the victims of the vampire's attacks, B. They are the vampire's minions, C. They are the vampire slayers, D. They are the detectives trying to solve the mystery Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the Egyptian Book of the Dead,
there’s a banishment spell that declares, “Be far from me, 
O vile cockroach.” More than 3,000 years later, 
we’re still trying to oust these insects. But from poison traps 
to hastily brandished slippers, cockroaches seem to weather 
just about everything we throw at them. So what makes cockroaches so hard to kill? There are nearly 5,000 cockroach species. 99% of them live in a range of habitats
where they play important ecological roles by recycling dead or decaying 
organic matter and nourishing other animals. But a couple dozen species adapted to live
in close association with humans. German and American cockroaches
are among the most common. And they owe their resilience
to a combination of physical and chemical adaptations. When it comes to old-fashioned 
removal methods, they're troublingly tenacious. An American cockroach’s sensory hairs 
or structures pick up subtle air currents and rapidly send signals 
to its central nervous system. The roach can then turn and sprint
away within a few milliseconds. And it’s among the fastest invertebrates
ever recorded, reaching speeds of up to 50
body lengths per second. This would be the human equivalent of
running more than 300 kilometers per hour. And finding a hiding place is no problem. With its flattened, flexible body, an American cockroach can squeeze into 
spaces less than a quarter of its height. Even if we do land a hit, 
it can withstand compressive forces of up to 900 times its own weight 
by distributing the impact along its body. And the cockroach’s toughness
doesn’t end there. Cockroaches can eat a variety 
of organic matter, including hair, dead skin, 
adhesives, and paper. This is made possible by an expansive set 
of digestive enzymes. Cockroaches are able to thrive 
even in nutrient-poor environments. Roaches often eat decaying foods
that are low in nitrogen— an essential component
of DNA and proteins. But they survive by storing 
nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and having a resident group
of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s 
immune system efficiently unleashes many antimicrobial molecules. Cockroaches also have a slew of defenses
against pesticides. When a non-resistant roach walks 
on a surface that’s been sprayed with a pyrethroid insecticide, 
for example, the results will likely be fatal. Once absorbed, the chemical binds
to sodium channel proteins, which help propagate nerve impulses. The pyrethroid keeps 
the sodium channels open, so the nerves fire repeatedly. And soon, the cockroach dies. But if a resistant roach is exposed 
to pyrethroids, it’ll be just fine. Genetic mutations have given
them sodium channels that the pyrethroids can’t bind to. The cockroach also produces more
detoxification enzymes, which render the pesticide harmless, and the cockroach simply excretes 
it as a waste. Because German cockroaches
reproduce especially quickly, populations may evolve resistance 
to a new pesticide within months. So far, they're already resistant
to 43 different chemicals. But contrary to popular belief, cockroaches would probably not survive 
a nuclear apocalypse. Compared with other insects, cockroaches are only mildly
tolerant to radiation. They would die near the sites
of nuclear explosions and would still be severely
compromised miles away. Moreover, disasters that threaten humanity also jeopardize the habitats and buffets 
we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which factors do cockroaches owe their resilience to?
Options: A. Physical and chemical adaptations, B. Environmental factors, C. Psychiatric factors, D. None of the above
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated number of cockroach species that exist? Options: A. 1,000, B. 5,000, C. 10,000, D. 20,000 Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which two cockroach species are among the most common to live in close association with humans? Options: A. German and American, B. Asian and Australian, C. European and African, D. South American and Canadian Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of an American cockroach's sensory hairs or structures? Options: A. To detect light, B. To detect sound, C. To pick up subtle air currents, D. To detect temperature Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the estimated speed of an American cockroach in terms of body lengths per second? Options: A. 10, B. 20, C. 30, D. 50 Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is unique about a cockroach's digestive system that allows it to thrive in nutrient-poor environments? Options: A. It has a small set of digestive enzymes, B. It has an expansive set of digestive enzymes, C. It has no digestive enzymes, D. It only eats high-nitrogen foods Correct Option: None
Question 6: How do cockroaches survive in environments with low nitrogen availability? Options: A. They store nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and have bacteria recycle it, B. They only eat high-nitrogen foods, C. They have a specialized organ to produce nitrogen, D. They do not need nitrogen to survive Correct Option: None
Question 7: What provides immunity to cockroaches against numerous pathogens? Options: A. Their diet, B. Their environment, C. Genes that provide immunity, D. Their behavior Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do resistant cockroaches respond to pyrethroid insecticides? Options: A. They die immediately, B. They are unaffected due to genetic mutations, C. They become more aggressive, D. They change color Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why are cockroaches unlikely to survive a nuclear apocalypse? Options: A. They are highly tolerant to radiation, B. They are only mildly tolerant to radiation, C. They would thrive in a radioactive environment, D. They would evolve to become more resistant Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is a consequence of German cockroaches reproducing quickly? Options: A. They become more susceptible to pesticides, B. They evolve resistance to pesticides more slowly, C. They evolve resistance to pesticides within months, D. They do not evolve resistance to pesticides Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, based on the information provided in the transcript, the closest match can be inferred as follows:

The ground truth MCQ asks about the factors that contribute to cockroaches' resilience. According to the transcript, cockroaches owe their resilience to a combination of physical and chemical adaptations.

Among the generated MCQs, none directly address the factors contributing to cockroaches' resilience. However, some MCQs touch upon specific aspects of their physical and chemical adaptations.

Considering the intent and content of the ground truth MCQ, the closest match would be a generated MCQ that addresses cockroaches' adaptations or resilience. While there isn't a direct match, Question 7: "What provides immunity to cockroaches against numerous pathogens?" is related to their chemical adaptations (i.e., genes providing immunity).

However, since this is not a direct match, I must emphasize that the provided generated MCQs do not adequately match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the closest match based on the available options, I would say that Question 7 is the closest, but with a significant caveat that it's not an ideal match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7 (with the caveat mentioned above)

of nuclear explosions and would still be severely
compromised miles away. Moreover, disasters that threaten humanity also jeopardize the habitats and buffets 
we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The ability of pest cockroaches such as the American cockroach to escape stomping attempts by humans can be attributed to which of the following characteristics.
Options: A. Walking or running speed, B. Flattened and flexible body, C. Both “a” and “b”, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated number of cockroach species that exist? Options: A. 1,000, B. 5,000, C. 10,000, D. 20,000 Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which two cockroach species are among the most common to live in close association with humans? Options: A. German and American, B. Asian and Australian, C. European and African, D. South American and Canadian Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of an American cockroach's sensory hairs or structures? Options: A. To detect light, B. To detect sound, C. To pick up subtle air currents, D. To detect temperature Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the estimated speed of an American cockroach in terms of body lengths per second? Options: A. 10, B. 20, C. 30, D. 50 Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is unique about a cockroach's digestive system that allows it to thrive in nutrient-poor environments? Options: A. It has a small set of digestive enzymes, B. It has an expansive set of digestive enzymes, C. It has no digestive enzymes, D. It only eats high-nitrogen foods Correct Option: None
Question 6: How do cockroaches survive in environments with low nitrogen availability? Options: A. They store nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and have bacteria recycle it, B. They only eat high-nitrogen foods, C. They have a specialized organ to produce nitrogen, D. They do not need nitrogen to survive Correct Option: None
Question 7: What provides immunity to cockroaches against numerous pathogens? Options: A. Their diet, B. Their environment, C. Genes that provide immunity, D. Their behavior Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do resistant cockroaches respond to pyrethroid insecticides? Options: A. They die immediately, B. They are unaffected due to genetic mutations, C. They become more aggressive, D. They change color Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why are cockroaches unlikely to survive a nuclear apocalypse? Options: A. They are highly tolerant to radiation, B. They are only mildly tolerant to radiation, C. They would thrive in a radioactive environment, D. They would evolve to become more resistant Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is a consequence of German cockroaches reproducing quickly? Options: A. They become more susceptible to pesticides, B. They evolve resistance to pesticides more slowly, C. They evolve resistance to pesticides within months, D. They do not evolve resistance to pesticides Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the Egyptian Book of the Dead,
there’s a banishment spell that declares, “Be far from me, 
O vile cockroach.” More than 3,000 years later, 
we’re still trying to oust these insects. But from poison traps 
to hastily brandished slippers, cockroaches seem to weather 
just about everything we throw at them. So what makes cockroaches so hard to kill? There are nearly 5,000 cockroach species. 99% of them live in a range of habitats
where they play important ecological roles by recycling dead or decaying 
organic matter and nourishing other animals. But a couple dozen species adapted to live
in close association with humans. German and American cockroaches
are among the most common. And they owe their resilience
to a combination of physical and chemical adaptations. When it comes to old-fashioned 
removal methods, they're troublingly tenacious. An American cockroach’s sensory hairs 
or structures pick up subtle air currents and rapidly send signals 
to its central nervous system. The roach can then turn and sprint
away within a few milliseconds. And it’s among the fastest invertebrates
ever recorded, reaching speeds of up to 50
body lengths per second. This would be the human equivalent of
running more than 300 kilometers per hour. And finding a hiding place is no problem. With its flattened, flexible body, an American cockroach can squeeze into 
spaces less than a quarter of its height. Even if we do land a hit, 
it can withstand compressive forces of up to 900 times its own weight 
by distributing the impact along its body. And the cockroach’s toughness
doesn’t end there. Cockroaches can eat a variety 
of organic matter, including hair, dead skin, 
adhesives, and paper. This is made possible by an expansive set 
of digestive enzymes. Cockroaches are able to thrive 
even in nutrient-poor environments. Roaches often eat decaying foods
that are low in nitrogen— an essential component
of DNA and proteins. But they survive by storing 
nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and having a resident group
of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s 
immune system efficiently unleashes many antimicrobial molecules. Cockroaches also have a slew of defenses
against pesticides. When a non-resistant roach walks 
on a surface that’s been sprayed with a pyrethroid insecticide, 
for example, the results will likely be fatal. Once absorbed, the chemical binds
to sodium channel proteins, which help propagate nerve impulses. The pyrethroid keeps 
the sodium channels open, so the nerves fire repeatedly. And soon, the cockroach dies. But if a resistant roach is exposed 
to pyrethroids, it’ll be just fine. Genetic mutations have given
them sodium channels that the pyrethroids can’t bind to. The cockroach also produces more
detoxification enzymes, which render the pesticide harmless, and the cockroach simply excretes 
it as a waste. Because German cockroaches
reproduce especially quickly, populations may evolve resistance 
to a new pesticide within months. So far, they're already resistant
to 43 different chemicals. But contrary to popular belief, cockroaches would probably not survive 
a nuclear apocalypse. Compared with other insects, cockroaches are only mildly
tolerant to radiation. They would die near the sites
of nuclear explosions and would still be severely
compromised miles away. Moreover, disasters that threaten humanity also jeopardize the habitats and buffets 
we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which word or term best describes the dietary preference of pest cockroaches such as the German and American cockroach?
Options: A. Vegetarian, B. Carnivorous, C. Omnivorous, D. Eggetarian
Correct Option: C

Question 6: How do cockroaches survive in environments with low nitrogen availability? Options: A. They store nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and have bacteria recycle it, B. They only eat high-nitrogen foods, C. They have a specialized organ to produce nitrogen, D. They do not need nitrogen to survive Correct Option: None
Question 7: What provides immunity to cockroaches against numerous pathogens? Options: A. Their diet, B. Their environment, C. Genes that provide immunity, D. Their behavior Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do resistant cockroaches respond to pyrethroid insecticides? Options: A. They die immediately, B. They are unaffected due to genetic mutations, C. They become more aggressive, D. They change color Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why are cockroaches unlikely to survive a nuclear apocalypse? Options: A. They are highly tolerant to radiation, B. They are only mildly tolerant to radiation, C. They would thrive in a radioactive environment, D. They would evolve to become more resistant Correct Option: None

They evolve resistance to pesticides within months, D. They do not evolve resistance to pesticides Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

Although Question 5 does not directly ask about the dietary preference of pest cockroaches, it does relate to their ability to thrive in nutrient-poor environments due to their digestive system. The correct option, "It has an expansive set of digestive enzymes," implies that cockroaches are able to eat a wide variety of organic matter, which aligns with the concept of being omnivorous.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and options. 

If I had to choose an index, I would choose Question 5 (Index 5).

we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

Options: A. Detoxification enzymes, B. Mutations in the target site proteins, C. None of the above
Correct Option: B

there’s a banishment spell that declares, “Be far from me, 
O vile cockroach.” More than 3,000 years later, 
we’re still trying to oust these insects. But from poison traps 
to hastily brandished slippers, cockroaches seem to weather 
just about everything we throw at them. So what makes cockroaches so hard to kill? There are nearly 5,000 cockroach species. 99% of them live in a range of habitats
where they play important ecological roles by recycling dead or decaying 
organic matter and nourishing other animals. But a couple dozen species adapted to live

are among the most common. And they owe their resilience
to a combination of physical and chemical adaptations. When it comes to old-fashioned

to its central nervous system. The roach can then turn and sprint
away within a few milliseconds. And it’s among the fastest invertebrates
ever recorded, reaching speeds of up to 50

by distributing the impact along its body. And the cockroach’s toughness
doesn’t end there. Cockroaches can eat a variety

adhesives, and paper. This is made possible by an expansive set 
of digestive enzymes. Cockroaches are able to thrive 
even in nutrient-poor environments. Roaches often eat decaying foods
that are low in nitrogen— an essential component
of DNA and proteins. But they survive by storing 
nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and having a resident group
of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s
