Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year before the ancient Greeks
sowed their seeds of grain, they celebrated Demeter, 
the goddess of agriculture. On Earth, each morsel of food 
was sweet sustenance, while in the land of the dead,
it ensured a permanent stay. Demeter tended to Earth’s fields 
with her beloved daughter, Persephone, who inherited her mother’s passions
and grew into a bright young woman. But all the while, a shadowy figure
watched from below. One day, Persephone was frolicking
in a meadow with a freshwater nymph, Cyane. As they admired a blooming
narcissus flower, they noticed it tremble in the ground. Suddenly, the earth split, 
and a terrifying figure arose. It was Hades, god of the dead
and the underworld. He wrenched Persephone from Cyane,
dragged her into his inky chariot, and blasted back through the earth. Cyane wept so hard she dissolved,
becoming one with the river. By the time Demeter arrived 
at the scene of the abduction, the crater in the meadow had closed—
and Cyane and Persephone had vanished. Demeter sped to Mount Olympus for help. Many of the gods had witnessed the scene. And they knew about the deal 
that paved the way for it: Zeus, Persephone’s father, 
had granted Hades her hand in marriage without her consent— or Demeter’s. But when faced with Demeter’s pleas, 
the other gods stayed silent, So, she searched alone. In her grief and desperation, 
she neglected her usual tasks. Crops withered, and a great famine 
plagued the Earth. As mortals began to perish, 
the gods grew wary. Who would worship them and 
offer tributes if the humans disappeared? So, Zeus ordered Demeter to stop 
her crusade and returned to her duties. But she refused. Deep below, across the frigid river Styx,
and through the halls of the underworld, Persephone was waging her own protest. Hades expected her to serve
as his wife and queen. But Persephone rebuffed the god’s advances
and refused food. As she longed for her mother’s company, her friends’ laughter,
and the sun’s warmth, Persephone grew colder and lonelier. And she was starving. She hungered for satisfying grains,
crisp vegetables and fresh fruit. Wandering the ghostly gardens, she contemplated the pomegranates 
that hung heavily on their branches... Meanwhile, Demeter continued her hunt. She appealed to the all-seeing sun god,
Helios, whose rays had long warmed her crops. Indeed, when Helios drew his golden
chariot across the sky that fateful day, he saw what happened— 
and he knew of the deal. Out of respect and sympathy for Demeter, Helios told her of Hades’ demands,
Zeus’ betrayal and Persephone’s abduction. Furious and heartbroken, Demeter sped
to Mount Olympus and confronted Zeus, demanding their daughter’s return. But Zeus declined: in her ravenous hunger, Persephone had eaten a few seeds from the 
pomegranate that grew in the underworld. Though a meager amount, it was enough
to ensnare her in Hades forever. Demeter wouldn't accept this fate. She swore that if she wasn’t
reunited with Persephone, the fields would never be fertile again, and the distinction between the Earth 
and the underworld would soon dissolve. So, they made a pact. For two thirds of every year, Persephone 
would return to the land of the living, But for the remainder, she would stay 
in the world of the dead. When Persephone ascended to Earth,
she and her mother rejoiced. Together, they showered the fields 
with rain and nurtured them with sun. For mortals, Persephone’s arrival came
to herald the start of spring. But her descent always came too soon. Each time she returned to Hades, 
Demeter mourned, and the earth grew cold, 
dark, and unyielding, ushering in the winter months. Knowing Demeter couldn’t be roused 
from her grief, the humans stored their crops, 
stoked their fires, and awaited Persephone’s safe return. And so it was that her transit marked
the gradual turning of the seasons and the bittersweet compromise
between life and death.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Demeter was the Greek goddess of:
Options: A. Love, B. Agriculture, C. Animals, D. Parenthood
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the goddess of agriculture in ancient Greek mythology? Options: A. Persephone, B. Demeter, C. Cyane, D. Hera Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the result of Demeter's grief and desperation after Persephone's abduction? Options: A. The gods became more powerful, B. Crops flourished, and a great harvest occurred, C. Crops withered, and a great famine plagued the Earth, D. The seasons became longer Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why did Zeus order Demeter to stop her crusade and return to her duties? Options: A. He felt sorry for Demeter, B. He was afraid of Hades, C. The gods grew wary as mortals began to perish, and they needed humans to worship them, D. He wanted to punish Demeter Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the deal that Zeus made without Persephone's or Demeter's consent? Options: A. He granted Hades the power to control the seasons, B. He granted Hades Persephone's hand in marriage, C. He granted Demeter the power to control the underworld, D. He granted Persephone the power to control the gods Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why did Persephone eat the pomegranate seeds in the underworld? Options: A. She was tempted by their sweetness, B. She was trying to escape the underworld, C. She was hungry and longed for food, D. She was forced to eat them by Hades Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the result of Persephone eating the pomegranate seeds? Options: A. She was allowed to return to the land of the living forever, B. She was forced to stay in the underworld forever, C. She was allowed to return to the land of the living for part of the year, D. She was turned into a goddess Correct Option: None
Question 7: What marked the start of spring in ancient Greek mythology? Options: A. Persephone's descent into the underworld, B. Persephone's arrival in the land of the living, C. Demeter's grief and desperation, D. The gods' decision to control the seasons Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the compromise made between Demeter and the gods? Options: A. Persephone would stay in the underworld forever, B. Persephone would return to the land of the living for two-thirds of the year, C. Demeter would control the seasons, D. The gods would control the harvest Correct Option: None
Question 9: How did the humans prepare for Persephone's return to the underworld? Options: A. They celebrated with feasts and festivals, B. They stored their crops, stoked their fires, and awaited her safe return, C. They ignored the changing of the seasons, D. They tried to rescue Persephone from the underworld Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the significance of Persephone's transit between the land of the living and the underworld? Options: A. It marked the end of the harvest season, B. It marked the beginning of the gods' control over the seasons, C. It marked the gradual turning of the seasons and the bittersweet compromise between life and death, D. It marked the start of a great famine Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year before the ancient Greeks
sowed their seeds of grain, they celebrated Demeter, 
the goddess of agriculture. On Earth, each morsel of food 
was sweet sustenance, while in the land of the dead,
it ensured a permanent stay. Demeter tended to Earth’s fields 
with her beloved daughter, Persephone, who inherited her mother’s passions
and grew into a bright young woman. But all the while, a shadowy figure
watched from below. One day, Persephone was frolicking
in a meadow with a freshwater nymph, Cyane. As they admired a blooming
narcissus flower, they noticed it tremble in the ground. Suddenly, the earth split, 
and a terrifying figure arose. It was Hades, god of the dead
and the underworld. He wrenched Persephone from Cyane,
dragged her into his inky chariot, and blasted back through the earth. Cyane wept so hard she dissolved,
becoming one with the river. By the time Demeter arrived 
at the scene of the abduction, the crater in the meadow had closed—
and Cyane and Persephone had vanished. Demeter sped to Mount Olympus for help. Many of the gods had witnessed the scene. And they knew about the deal 
that paved the way for it: Zeus, Persephone’s father, 
had granted Hades her hand in marriage without her consent— or Demeter’s. But when faced with Demeter’s pleas, 
the other gods stayed silent, So, she searched alone. In her grief and desperation, 
she neglected her usual tasks. Crops withered, and a great famine 
plagued the Earth. As mortals began to perish, 
the gods grew wary. Who would worship them and 
offer tributes if the humans disappeared? So, Zeus ordered Demeter to stop 
her crusade and returned to her duties. But she refused. Deep below, across the frigid river Styx,
and through the halls of the underworld, Persephone was waging her own protest. Hades expected her to serve
as his wife and queen. But Persephone rebuffed the god’s advances
and refused food. As she longed for her mother’s company, her friends’ laughter,
and the sun’s warmth, Persephone grew colder and lonelier. And she was starving. She hungered for satisfying grains,
crisp vegetables and fresh fruit. Wandering the ghostly gardens, she contemplated the pomegranates 
that hung heavily on their branches... Meanwhile, Demeter continued her hunt. She appealed to the all-seeing sun god,
Helios, whose rays had long warmed her crops. Indeed, when Helios drew his golden
chariot across the sky that fateful day, he saw what happened— 
and he knew of the deal. Out of respect and sympathy for Demeter, Helios told her of Hades’ demands,
Zeus’ betrayal and Persephone’s abduction. Furious and heartbroken, Demeter sped
to Mount Olympus and confronted Zeus, demanding their daughter’s return. But Zeus declined: in her ravenous hunger, Persephone had eaten a few seeds from the 
pomegranate that grew in the underworld. Though a meager amount, it was enough
to ensnare her in Hades forever. Demeter wouldn't accept this fate. She swore that if she wasn’t
reunited with Persephone, the fields would never be fertile again, and the distinction between the Earth 
and the underworld would soon dissolve. So, they made a pact. For two thirds of every year, Persephone 
would return to the land of the living, But for the remainder, she would stay 
in the world of the dead. When Persephone ascended to Earth,
she and her mother rejoiced. Together, they showered the fields 
with rain and nurtured them with sun. For mortals, Persephone’s arrival came
to herald the start of spring. But her descent always came too soon. Each time she returned to Hades, 
Demeter mourned, and the earth grew cold, 
dark, and unyielding, ushering in the winter months. Knowing Demeter couldn’t be roused 
from her grief, the humans stored their crops, 
stoked their fires, and awaited Persephone’s safe return. And so it was that her transit marked
the gradual turning of the seasons and the bittersweet compromise
between life and death.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Persephone’s father was
Options: A. Apollo, B. Hermes, C. Zeus , D. Mars 
Correct Option: C

Persephone would return to the land of the living for two-thirds of the year, C. Demeter would control the seasons, D. The gods would control the harvest Correct Option: None

It marked the start of a great famine Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Although the options in Question 4 do not directly ask for Persephone's father, option B states "He granted Hades Persephone's hand in marriage," which implies that Zeus is Persephone's father, as he is granting her hand in marriage. This is the closest match to the ground truth MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Every year before the ancient Greeks
sowed their seeds of grain, they celebrated Demeter, 
the goddess of agriculture. On Earth, each morsel of food 
was sweet sustenance, while in the land of the dead,
it ensured a permanent stay. Demeter tended to Earth’s fields 
with her beloved daughter, Persephone, who inherited her mother’s passions
and grew into a bright young woman. But all the while, a shadowy figure
watched from below. One day, Persephone was frolicking
in a meadow with a freshwater nymph, Cyane. As they admired a blooming
narcissus flower, they noticed it tremble in the ground. Suddenly, the earth split, 
and a terrifying figure arose. It was Hades, god of the dead
and the underworld. He wrenched Persephone from Cyane,
dragged her into his inky chariot, and blasted back through the earth. Cyane wept so hard she dissolved,
becoming one with the river. By the time Demeter arrived 
at the scene of the abduction, the crater in the meadow had closed—
and Cyane and Persephone had vanished. Demeter sped to Mount Olympus for help. Many of the gods had witnessed the scene. And they knew about the deal 
that paved the way for it: Zeus, Persephone’s father, 
had granted Hades her hand in marriage without her consent— or Demeter’s. But when faced with Demeter’s pleas, 
the other gods stayed silent, So, she searched alone. In her grief and desperation, 
she neglected her usual tasks. Crops withered, and a great famine 
plagued the Earth. As mortals began to perish, 
the gods grew wary. Who would worship them and 
offer tributes if the humans disappeared? So, Zeus ordered Demeter to stop 
her crusade and returned to her duties. But she refused. Deep below, across the frigid river Styx,
and through the halls of the underworld, Persephone was waging her own protest. Hades expected her to serve
as his wife and queen. But Persephone rebuffed the god’s advances
and refused food. As she longed for her mother’s company, her friends’ laughter,
and the sun’s warmth, Persephone grew colder and lonelier. And she was starving. She hungered for satisfying grains,
crisp vegetables and fresh fruit. Wandering the ghostly gardens, she contemplated the pomegranates 
that hung heavily on their branches... Meanwhile, Demeter continued her hunt. She appealed to the all-seeing sun god,
Helios, whose rays had long warmed her crops. Indeed, when Helios drew his golden
chariot across the sky that fateful day, he saw what happened— 
and he knew of the deal. Out of respect and sympathy for Demeter, Helios told her of Hades’ demands,
Zeus’ betrayal and Persephone’s abduction. Furious and heartbroken, Demeter sped
to Mount Olympus and confronted Zeus, demanding their daughter’s return. But Zeus declined: in her ravenous hunger, Persephone had eaten a few seeds from the 
pomegranate that grew in the underworld. Though a meager amount, it was enough
to ensnare her in Hades forever. Demeter wouldn't accept this fate. She swore that if she wasn’t
reunited with Persephone, the fields would never be fertile again, and the distinction between the Earth 
and the underworld would soon dissolve. So, they made a pact. For two thirds of every year, Persephone 
would return to the land of the living, But for the remainder, she would stay 
in the world of the dead. When Persephone ascended to Earth,
she and her mother rejoiced. Together, they showered the fields 
with rain and nurtured them with sun. For mortals, Persephone’s arrival came
to herald the start of spring. But her descent always came too soon. Each time she returned to Hades, 
Demeter mourned, and the earth grew cold, 
dark, and unyielding, ushering in the winter months. Knowing Demeter couldn’t be roused 
from her grief, the humans stored their crops, 
stoked their fires, and awaited Persephone’s safe return. And so it was that her transit marked
the gradual turning of the seasons and the bittersweet compromise
between life and death.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What would doom Persephone to the underworld?
Options: A. If she ate the food of the underworld, B. If she agreed to serve as Hades’ queen , C. If she slept one night in the underworld , D. If she contacted her mother
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
Every year before the ancient Greeks
sowed their seeds of grain, they celebrated Demeter, 
the goddess of agriculture. On Earth, each morsel of food 
was sweet sustenance, while in the land of the dead,
it ensured a permanent stay. Demeter tended to Earth’s fields 
with her beloved daughter, Persephone, who inherited her mother’s passions
and grew into a bright young woman. But all the while, a shadowy figure
watched from below. One day, Persephone was frolicking
in a meadow with a freshwater nymph, Cyane. As they admired a blooming
narcissus flower, they noticed it tremble in the ground. Suddenly, the earth split, 
and a terrifying figure arose. It was Hades, god of the dead
and the underworld. He wrenched Persephone from Cyane,
dragged her into his inky chariot, and blasted back through the earth. Cyane wept so hard she dissolved,
becoming one with the river. By the time Demeter arrived 
at the scene of the abduction, the crater in the meadow had closed—
and Cyane and Persephone had vanished. Demeter sped to Mount Olympus for help. Many of the gods had witnessed the scene. And they knew about the deal 
that paved the way for it: Zeus, Persephone’s father, 
had granted Hades her hand in marriage without her consent— or Demeter’s. But when faced with Demeter’s pleas, 
the other gods stayed silent, So, she searched alone. In her grief and desperation, 
she neglected her usual tasks. Crops withered, and a great famine 
plagued the Earth. As mortals began to perish, 
the gods grew wary. Who would worship them and 
offer tributes if the humans disappeared? So, Zeus ordered Demeter to stop 
her crusade and returned to her duties. But she refused. Deep below, across the frigid river Styx,
and through the halls of the underworld, Persephone was waging her own protest. Hades expected her to serve
as his wife and queen. But Persephone rebuffed the god’s advances
and refused food. As she longed for her mother’s company, her friends’ laughter,
and the sun’s warmth, Persephone grew colder and lonelier. And she was starving. She hungered for satisfying grains,
crisp vegetables and fresh fruit. Wandering the ghostly gardens, she contemplated the pomegranates 
that hung heavily on their branches... Meanwhile, Demeter continued her hunt. She appealed to the all-seeing sun god,
Helios, whose rays had long warmed her crops. Indeed, when Helios drew his golden
chariot across the sky that fateful day, he saw what happened— 
and he knew of the deal. Out of respect and sympathy for Demeter, Helios told her of Hades’ demands,
Zeus’ betrayal and Persephone’s abduction. Furious and heartbroken, Demeter sped
to Mount Olympus and confronted Zeus, demanding their daughter’s return. But Zeus declined: in her ravenous hunger, Persephone had eaten a few seeds from the 
pomegranate that grew in the underworld. Though a meager amount, it was enough
to ensnare her in Hades forever. Demeter wouldn't accept this fate. She swore that if she wasn’t
reunited with Persephone, the fields would never be fertile again, and the distinction between the Earth 
and the underworld would soon dissolve. So, they made a pact. For two thirds of every year, Persephone 
would return to the land of the living, But for the remainder, she would stay 
in the world of the dead. When Persephone ascended to Earth,
she and her mother rejoiced. Together, they showered the fields 
with rain and nurtured them with sun. For mortals, Persephone’s arrival came
to herald the start of spring. But her descent always came too soon. Each time she returned to Hades, 
Demeter mourned, and the earth grew cold, 
dark, and unyielding, ushering in the winter months. Knowing Demeter couldn’t be roused 
from her grief, the humans stored their crops, 
stoked their fires, and awaited Persephone’s safe return. And so it was that her transit marked
the gradual turning of the seasons and the bittersweet compromise
between life and death.

**Transcript**:
Every year before the ancient Greeks
sowed their seeds of grain, they celebrated Demeter, 
the goddess of agriculture. On Earth, each morsel of food 
was sweet sustenance, while in the land of the dead,
it ensured a permanent stay. Demeter tended to Earth’s fields 
with her beloved daughter, Persephone, who inherited her mother’s passions
and grew into a bright young woman. But all the while, a shadowy figure
watched from below. One day, Persephone was frolicking
in a meadow with a freshwater nymph, Cyane. As they admired a blooming
narcissus flower, they noticed it tremble in the ground. Suddenly, the earth split, 
and a terrifying figure arose. It was Hades, god of the dead
and the underworld. He wrenched Persephone from Cyane,
dragged her into his inky chariot, and blasted back through the earth. Cyane wept so hard she dissolved,
becoming one with the river. By the time Demeter arrived 
at the scene of the abduction, the crater in the meadow had closed—
and Cyane and Persephone had vanished. Demeter sped to Mount Olympus for help. Many of the gods had witnessed the scene. And they knew about the deal 
that paved the way for it: Zeus, Persephone’s father, 
had granted Hades her hand in marriage without her consent— or Demeter’s. But when faced with Demeter’s pleas, 
the other gods stayed silent, So, she searched alone. In her grief and desperation, 
she neglected her usual tasks. Crops withered, and a great famine 
plagued the Earth. As mortals began to perish, 
the gods grew wary. Who would worship them and 
offer tributes if the humans disappeared? So, Zeus ordered Demeter to stop 
her crusade and returned to her duties. But she refused. Deep below, across the frigid river Styx,
and through the halls of the underworld, Persephone was waging her own protest. Hades expected her to serve
as his wife and queen. But Persephone rebuffed the god’s advances
and refused food. As she longed for her mother’s company, her friends’ laughter,
and the sun’s warmth, Persephone grew colder and lonelier. And she was starving. She hungered for satisfying grains,
crisp vegetables and fresh fruit. Wandering the ghostly gardens, she contemplated the pomegranates 
that hung heavily on their branches... Meanwhile, Demeter continued her hunt. She appealed to the all-seeing sun god,
Helios, whose rays had long warmed her crops. Indeed, when Helios drew his golden
chariot across the sky that fateful day, he saw what happened— 
and he knew of the deal. Out of respect and sympathy for Demeter, Helios told her of Hades’ demands,
Zeus’ betrayal and Persephone’s abduction. Furious and heartbroken, Demeter sped
to Mount Olympus and confronted Zeus, demanding their daughter’s return. But Zeus declined: in her ravenous hunger, Persephone had eaten a few seeds from the 
pomegranate that grew in the underworld. Though a meager amount, it was enough
to ensnare her in Hades forever. Demeter wouldn't accept this fate. She swore that if she wasn’t
reunited with Persephone, the fields would never be fertile again, and the distinction between the Earth 
and the underworld would soon dissolve. So, they made a pact. For two thirds of every year, Persephone 
would return to the land of the living, But for the remainder, she would stay 
in the world of the dead. When Persephone ascended to Earth,
she and her mother rejoiced. Together, they showered the fields 
with rain and nurtured them with sun. For mortals, Persephone’s arrival came
to herald the start of spring. But her descent always came too soon. Each time she returned to Hades, 
Demeter mourned, and the earth grew cold, 
dark, and unyielding, ushering in the winter months. Knowing Demeter couldn’t be roused 
from her grief, the humans stored their crops, 
stoked their fires, and awaited Persephone’s safe return. And so it was that her transit marked
the gradual turning of the seasons and the bittersweet compromise
between life and death.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the end, what portion of the year did Persephone spend in the World of the Living?
Options: A. 1/3, B. 2/3, C. 3/4, D. 1/4
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You’re sitting on the couch watching TV,
when you hear a knock on the door. The police have just arrived 
to arrest your spouse— for murder. This accusation comes as a total shock. In your experience, your partner has
always been gentle and loving, and you can't imagine them committing
a grisly murder. But the evidence is serious: their fingerprints were found
on the murder weapon. Your spouse insists they're innocent. “I know it looks bad,” they say,
“but you have to believe me! If you don’t, who will?” Should you believe your spouse, even though the evidence 
against them looks damning? Take a second to think what you would
believe in this situation. This dilemma is part of what philosophers
call the ethics of belief: a field of study that explores 
how we ought to form beliefs, and whether we have ethical duties
to believe certain things. The question here isn't about
what you should do, such as whether or not you should find
your spouse guilty in a court of law. After all, you wouldn’t be on the jury
in their trial! Rather, it’s about what you should believe
to be true. So, what factors should you consider? Perhaps the most obvious is your evidence. After all, to believe something
is to take it to be true. And evidence is, by definition, all information that helps
us determine what's true. From this, some philosophers draw
the conclusion that evidence is the only thing that ought 
to determine what you believe. This view is called evidentialism,
and a strict evidentialist would say it doesn’t matter that the accused 
is your spouse. You should evaluate the evidence 
from a neutral, objective point of view. Taking the perspective 
of an unbiased third party, your judgment of your spouse's character
is a relevant consideration. But finding their fingerprints 
at the crime scene is surely stronger evidence. So, from an evidentialist point of view, you should either believe 
your spouse is guilty, or at best remain undecided. Some philosophers present
evidentialism only as a view of what’s most rational to believe. But others, like 19th century 
evidentialist W.K. Clifford, think that following the evidence
is also morally required. One argument for this view is that 
having well-informed, accurate beliefs is often vitally important to determining 
the ethical way to act. Another argument is that there’s something
unethical about being dishonest, and refusing to follow the evidence is 
a way of being dishonest with oneself. However, perhaps there are other
ethical factors in play. Although the evidence against
your spouse is strong, there’s still a chance that
they’re actually innocent. Think for a moment about how 
it would feel to be innocent, and have no one believe you—
not even your own partner! By not trusting your spouse, you run the risk of seriously hurting
them in their crucial hour of need. Moreover, consider what this lack 
of trust would do to your marriage. It would be incredibly difficult 
to continue a loving relationship with someone that you believed—
or even strongly suspected— was a murderer. You might try to pretend to believe
that your spouse is innocent, but could you really 
go on living that lie? According to a theory of the ethics 
of belief called pragmatism, these kinds of practical considerations
can sometimes make it right to believe something
even without strong evidence. Some pragmatists would even say 
that you morally owe it to your spouse to believe them. But is it even possible to believe
your spouse is innocent just because you think it’ll be good
for your relationship? Or because you think you owe
it to the accused? You might desperately want 
to believe they’re innocent, but can you control your beliefs in the
same way you control your actions? It seems like you can’t just believe
whatever you like when the truth is staring you in the face. But on the other hand, 
recall your spouse’s plea. When we say things like this, we seem to be assuming that it is possible
to control our beliefs in some way. So what do you think? 
Can you control what beliefs you have? And if so, what will you believe
about your spouse?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the ‘ethics of belief’?
Options: A. A field of psychology exploring how we usually form beliefs, B. A field of psychology exploring how we ought to form beliefs, C.  A field of philosophy exploring how we usually form beliefs, D. A field of philosophy exploring how we ought to form beliefs
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary concern of the field of study known as the ethics of belief? Options: A. Determining the moral implications of a person's actions, B. Exploring how we ought to form beliefs and whether we have ethical duties to believe certain things, C. Examining the role of evidence in shaping our perceptions of reality, D. Investigating the relationship between morality and knowledge Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to evidentialism, what should be the sole determining factor in forming beliefs? Options: A. Personal experience and intuition, B. Evidence and objective analysis, C. Emotional attachment and loyalty, D. Social norms and expectations Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who is the 19th-century philosopher mentioned in the transcript as a proponent of evidentialism? Options: A. Immanuel Kant, B. John Stuart Mill, C. W.K. Clifford, D. Friedrich Nietzsche Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is one argument presented in the transcript for the moral requirement to follow evidence in forming beliefs? Options: A. Having well-informed, accurate beliefs is necessary for personal happiness, B. Refusing to follow evidence is a form of dishonesty with oneself, C. Following evidence is necessary for social cohesion and stability, D. Having well-informed, accurate beliefs is often vitally important to determining the ethical way to act Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the name of the theory that suggests practical considerations can sometimes make it right to believe something even without strong evidence? Options: A. Pragmatism, B. Evidentialism, C. Rationalism, D. Empiricism Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to pragmatism, what might be a reason to believe someone's innocence despite strong evidence to the contrary? Options: A. To avoid personal discomfort and anxiety, B. To maintain social norms and expectations, C. To preserve a loving relationship and avoid hurting the accused, D. To uphold the principle of objective justice Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the central question raised by the transcript regarding the nature of belief? Options: A. Can we control our actions in accordance with our beliefs?, B. Can we control what beliefs we have?, C. Are our beliefs determined by our environment and upbringing?, D. Are our beliefs shaped by our emotions and personal biases? Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the dilemma presented in the transcript that illustrates the complexities of the ethics of belief? Options: A. A person is accused of a crime and must decide whether to confess or deny guilt, B. A person's spouse is accused of murder and they must decide whether to believe their innocence, C. A person is faced with a difficult moral decision and must weigh competing values and principles, D. A person is confronted with conflicting evidence and must decide what to believe Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the role of evidence in the context of the ethics of belief, according to the transcript? Options: A. Evidence is the sole determining factor in forming beliefs, B. Evidence is one consideration among many in forming beliefs, C. Evidence is irrelevant to the formation of beliefs, D. Evidence is only relevant in certain contexts and situations Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the primary concern of the speaker in the transcript when considering whether to believe their spouse's innocence? Options: A. To uphold the principle of objective justice, B. To preserve their loving relationship and avoid hurting their spouse, C. To maintain social norms and expectations, D. To avoid personal discomfort and anxiety Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 1: What is the primary concern of the field of study known as the ethics of belief?**

Although the question wording is not identical, the intent and content of Question 1 are closest to the ground truth MCQ. Both questions aim to understand the definition and scope of the "ethics of belief." While the options in Question 1 do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, they still relate to the field of study and its primary concerns.

To make Question 1 more similar to the ground truth MCQ, the options could be revised to include the correct definition of the "ethics of belief" as a field of philosophy exploring how we ought to form beliefs.

You’re sitting on the couch watching TV,
when you hear a knock on the door. The police have just arrived 
to arrest your spouse— for murder. This accusation comes as a total shock. In your experience, your partner has
always been gentle and loving, and you can't imagine them committing

on the murder weapon. Your spouse insists they're innocent. “I know it looks bad,” they say,
“but you have to believe me! If you don’t, who will?” Should you believe your spouse, even though the evidence 
against them looks damning? Take a second to think what you would
believe in this situation. This dilemma is part of what philosophers
call the ethics of belief: a field of study that explores 
how we ought to form beliefs, and whether we have ethical duties
to believe certain things. The question here isn't about
what you should do, such as whether or not you should find

is a relevant consideration. But finding their fingerprints

a way of being dishonest with oneself. However, perhaps there are other

they’re actually innocent. Think for a moment about how 
it would feel to be innocent, and have no one believe you—
not even your own partner! By not trusting your spouse, you run the risk of seriously hurting
them in their crucial hour of need. Moreover, consider what this lack 
of trust would do to your marriage. It would be incredibly difficult

or even strongly suspected— was a murderer. You might try to pretend to believe

Options: A. Evidence is the information that is permitted in a court of law, B. Evidence is stuff that you can see, hear or touch, C. Evidence is your own personal belief system, D. Evidence is all information that helps us determine what’s true

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You’re sitting on the couch watching TV,
when you hear a knock on the door. The police have just arrived 
to arrest your spouse— for murder. This accusation comes as a total shock. In your experience, your partner has
always been gentle and loving, and you can't imagine them committing
a grisly murder. But the evidence is serious: their fingerprints were found
on the murder weapon. Your spouse insists they're innocent. “I know it looks bad,” they say,
“but you have to believe me! If you don’t, who will?” Should you believe your spouse, even though the evidence 
against them looks damning? Take a second to think what you would
believe in this situation. This dilemma is part of what philosophers
call the ethics of belief: a field of study that explores 
how we ought to form beliefs, and whether we have ethical duties
to believe certain things. The question here isn't about
what you should do, such as whether or not you should find
your spouse guilty in a court of law. After all, you wouldn’t be on the jury
in their trial! Rather, it’s about what you should believe
to be true. So, what factors should you consider? Perhaps the most obvious is your evidence. After all, to believe something
is to take it to be true. And evidence is, by definition, all information that helps
us determine what's true. From this, some philosophers draw
the conclusion that evidence is the only thing that ought 
to determine what you believe. This view is called evidentialism,
and a strict evidentialist would say it doesn’t matter that the accused 
is your spouse. You should evaluate the evidence 
from a neutral, objective point of view. Taking the perspective 
of an unbiased third party, your judgment of your spouse's character
is a relevant consideration. But finding their fingerprints 
at the crime scene is surely stronger evidence. So, from an evidentialist point of view, you should either believe 
your spouse is guilty, or at best remain undecided. Some philosophers present
evidentialism only as a view of what’s most rational to believe. But others, like 19th century 
evidentialist W.K. Clifford, think that following the evidence
is also morally required. One argument for this view is that 
having well-informed, accurate beliefs is often vitally important to determining 
the ethical way to act. Another argument is that there’s something
unethical about being dishonest, and refusing to follow the evidence is 
a way of being dishonest with oneself. However, perhaps there are other
ethical factors in play. Although the evidence against
your spouse is strong, there’s still a chance that
they’re actually innocent. Think for a moment about how 
it would feel to be innocent, and have no one believe you—
not even your own partner! By not trusting your spouse, you run the risk of seriously hurting
them in their crucial hour of need. Moreover, consider what this lack 
of trust would do to your marriage. It would be incredibly difficult 
to continue a loving relationship with someone that you believed—
or even strongly suspected— was a murderer. You might try to pretend to believe
that your spouse is innocent, but could you really 
go on living that lie? According to a theory of the ethics 
of belief called pragmatism, these kinds of practical considerations
can sometimes make it right to believe something
even without strong evidence. Some pragmatists would even say 
that you morally owe it to your spouse to believe them. But is it even possible to believe
your spouse is innocent just because you think it’ll be good
for your relationship? Or because you think you owe
it to the accused? You might desperately want 
to believe they’re innocent, but can you control your beliefs in the
same way you control your actions? It seems like you can’t just believe
whatever you like when the truth is staring you in the face. But on the other hand, 
recall your spouse’s plea. When we say things like this, we seem to be assuming that it is possible
to control our beliefs in some way. So what do you think? 
Can you control what beliefs you have? And if so, what will you believe
about your spouse?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the ‘evidentialist’ view about the ethics of belief?
Options: A. The view that evidence is one thing, among others, that ought to determine what you believe, B. The view that evidence is the only thing that ought to determine what you believe, C. The view evidence should never make a difference to what you believe, D. The view that no-one ever holds a belief that goes against their evidence
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary concern of the field of study known as the ethics of belief? Options: A. Determining the moral implications of a person's actions, B. Exploring how we ought to form beliefs and whether we have ethical duties to believe certain things, C. Examining the role of evidence in shaping our perceptions of reality, D. Investigating the relationship between morality and knowledge Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to evidentialism, what should be the sole determining factor in forming beliefs? Options: A. Personal experience and intuition, B. Evidence and objective analysis, C. Emotional attachment and loyalty, D. Social norms and expectations Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who is the 19th-century philosopher mentioned in the transcript as a proponent of evidentialism? Options: A. Immanuel Kant, B. John Stuart Mill, C. W.K. Clifford, D. Friedrich Nietzsche Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is one argument presented in the transcript for the moral requirement to follow evidence in forming beliefs? Options: A. Having well-informed, accurate beliefs is necessary for personal happiness, B. Refusing to follow evidence is a form of dishonesty with oneself, C. Following evidence is necessary for social cohesion and stability, D. Having well-informed, accurate beliefs is often vitally important to determining the ethical way to act Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the name of the theory that suggests practical considerations can sometimes make it right to believe something even without strong evidence? Options: A. Pragmatism, B. Evidentialism, C. Rationalism, D. Empiricism Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to pragmatism, what might be a reason to believe someone's innocence despite strong evidence to the contrary? Options: A. To avoid personal discomfort and anxiety, B. To maintain social norms and expectations, C. To preserve a loving relationship and avoid hurting the accused, D. To uphold the principle of objective justice Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the central question raised by the transcript regarding the nature of belief? Options: A. Can we control our actions in accordance with our beliefs?, B. Can we control what beliefs we have?, C. Are our beliefs determined by our environment and upbringing?, D. Are our beliefs shaped by our emotions and personal biases? Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the dilemma presented in the transcript that illustrates the complexities of the ethics of belief? Options: A. A person is accused of a crime and must decide whether to confess or deny guilt, B. A person's spouse is accused of murder and they must decide whether to believe their innocence, C. A person is faced with a difficult moral decision and must weigh competing values and principles, D. A person is confronted with conflicting evidence and must decide what to believe Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the role of evidence in the context of the ethics of belief, according to the transcript? Options: A. Evidence is the sole determining factor in forming beliefs, B. Evidence is one consideration among many in forming beliefs, C. Evidence is irrelevant to the formation of beliefs, D. Evidence is only relevant in certain contexts and situations Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the primary concern of the speaker in the transcript when considering whether to believe their spouse's innocence? Options: A. To uphold the principle of objective justice, B. To preserve their loving relationship and avoid hurting their spouse, C. To maintain social norms and expectations, D. To avoid personal discomfort and anxiety Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, as it specifically asks about the evidentialist view and its stance on the role of evidence in forming beliefs. The correct option in Question 2 (B. Evidence and objective analysis) is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (B. The view that evidence is the only thing that ought to determine what you believe), although the wording is not identical.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You’re sitting on the couch watching TV,
when you hear a knock on the door. The police have just arrived 
to arrest your spouse— for murder. This accusation comes as a total shock. In your experience, your partner has
always been gentle and loving, and you can't imagine them committing
a grisly murder. But the evidence is serious: their fingerprints were found
on the murder weapon. Your spouse insists they're innocent. “I know it looks bad,” they say,
“but you have to believe me! If you don’t, who will?” Should you believe your spouse, even though the evidence 
against them looks damning? Take a second to think what you would
believe in this situation. This dilemma is part of what philosophers
call the ethics of belief: a field of study that explores 
how we ought to form beliefs, and whether we have ethical duties
to believe certain things. The question here isn't about
what you should do, such as whether or not you should find
your spouse guilty in a court of law. After all, you wouldn’t be on the jury
in their trial! Rather, it’s about what you should believe
to be true. So, what factors should you consider? Perhaps the most obvious is your evidence. After all, to believe something
is to take it to be true. And evidence is, by definition, all information that helps
us determine what's true. From this, some philosophers draw
the conclusion that evidence is the only thing that ought 
to determine what you believe. This view is called evidentialism,
and a strict evidentialist would say it doesn’t matter that the accused 
is your spouse. You should evaluate the evidence 
from a neutral, objective point of view. Taking the perspective 
of an unbiased third party, your judgment of your spouse's character
is a relevant consideration. But finding their fingerprints 
at the crime scene is surely stronger evidence. So, from an evidentialist point of view, you should either believe 
your spouse is guilty, or at best remain undecided. Some philosophers present
evidentialism only as a view of what’s most rational to believe. But others, like 19th century 
evidentialist W.K. Clifford, think that following the evidence
is also morally required. One argument for this view is that 
having well-informed, accurate beliefs is often vitally important to determining 
the ethical way to act. Another argument is that there’s something
unethical about being dishonest, and refusing to follow the evidence is 
a way of being dishonest with oneself. However, perhaps there are other
ethical factors in play. Although the evidence against
your spouse is strong, there’s still a chance that
they’re actually innocent. Think for a moment about how 
it would feel to be innocent, and have no one believe you—
not even your own partner! By not trusting your spouse, you run the risk of seriously hurting
them in their crucial hour of need. Moreover, consider what this lack 
of trust would do to your marriage. It would be incredibly difficult 
to continue a loving relationship with someone that you believed—
or even strongly suspected— was a murderer. You might try to pretend to believe
that your spouse is innocent, but could you really 
go on living that lie? According to a theory of the ethics 
of belief called pragmatism, these kinds of practical considerations
can sometimes make it right to believe something
even without strong evidence. Some pragmatists would even say 
that you morally owe it to your spouse to believe them. But is it even possible to believe
your spouse is innocent just because you think it’ll be good
for your relationship? Or because you think you owe
it to the accused? You might desperately want 
to believe they’re innocent, but can you control your beliefs in the
same way you control your actions? It seems like you can’t just believe
whatever you like when the truth is staring you in the face. But on the other hand, 
recall your spouse’s plea. When we say things like this, we seem to be assuming that it is possible
to control our beliefs in some way. So what do you think? 
Can you control what beliefs you have? And if so, what will you believe
about your spouse?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the name of the view that opposes evidentialism?
Options: A. Moralism, B.  Practicalism, C. Pragmatism , D. Prudentialism
Correct Option: C

Investigating the relationship between morality and knowledge Correct Option: None

Following evidence is necessary for social cohesion and stability, D. Having well-informed, accurate beliefs is often vitally important to determining the ethical way to act Correct Option: None

To maintain social norms and expectations, C. To preserve a loving relationship and avoid hurting the accused, D. To uphold the principle of objective justice Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
We get it, not everyone loves snakes. You may not want to encounter one
in the wild. To each their own! That’s why we’re here, 
to take you on a world tour of some of nature’s most incredible snakes
from the safety of your home— and with your very own intrepid guide. All the snakes we’ll be visiting
belong to a group called the vipers. As of 2021, there are 368 species
of viper worldwide. The name comes from the term viviparity,
which means giving birth to live young. Unlike most snakes, which lay eggs, most vipers have eggs 
that hatch inside the mother, who then gives birth 
to up to dozens of tiny snakes. Not glad you’re safe at home yet? Vipers are also often highly venomous, with two hollow fangs that fold flat
to the roofs of their mouths. This allows the fangs to be extra long, unfolding into imposing weapons
when the viper prepares to strike. So how about we pay them a surprise visit? First stop: 
the southeastern United States, where we can hear the viper
before we can see it. The eastern diamondback rattlesnake is
the largest of 36 species of rattlesnake. Rattlesnakes can shake their rattles
up to 90 times per second to warn off predators 
for hours if needed. The rattle consists of hollow, interlocked
segments made of keratin, the same substance that makes
our nails and hair. When the snake shakes its tail,
these segments hit each other, creating a shockingly loud noise. Now onto the mountains of western Iran,
where a spider crawls across a rock, making easy prey for a passing bird—
or not. The spider-tailed horned viper is
perfectly camouflaged, almost invisible, except for its unique bulbous tail-tip
with long drooping scales that look like a leggy spider. Spider-tailed vipers
are only about 50 centimeters long, so they can lure small birds 
within striking range without compromising their ability 
to squeeze into narrow rock crevices. In the rainforests of Latin America 
lives a viper that couldn’t be more different
from the spider-tailed viper— if you can find it. It’s one of the most elusive snakes
in the world: the bushmaster. The bushmaster is a pit viper. Between each eye and nostril,
it has a heat-sensing pit with a membrane covered 
in highly sensitive receptors that respond to temperature changes as small as one one-thousandth 
of a degree Celsius. These pits gather infrared information
that is integrated with visual information in the optic tectum. This allows the bushmaster to “see” 
the heat signature of approaching prey or predators, helping it decide whether or not to strike
and strike more accurately. This comes in handy for guarding a nest— unlike most other vipers, 
the bushmaster lays eggs in hollowed out tree buttresses 
or burrows made by other animals. It must be large enough
to defend its nest— in fact, the bushmaster is the
largest viper in the world, reaching lengths of over 11 feet,
with huge fangs and deadly venom. Meanwhile, in the forests 
of sub-Saharan Africa, there’s a shorter, chunkier viper that’s 
even more venomous than the bushmaster. The African Gaboon viper has 
the longest fangs of any snake— yes, all 3,879 snake species, 
not just vipers— and can deliver 1,000 milligrams
of venom in a single bite— enough to kill ten adult humans. Although deadly, Gaboon vipers 
have a reputation for being slow-moving 
and placid creatures. When they do strike, they hold onto their 
rodent prey while the venom takes effect, then quickly swallow it down. At this point, you may be worrying
about our guide— but never fear, rodents like our little desert 
kangaroo rat have their own skills to evade the serpent’s tooth. They stomp their feet at rattlesnakes,
kick sand towards them, and evade their strikes 
with acrobatic leaps and powerful kicks— helping them live to guide 
another snake tour.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many viper species are there in the world?
Options: A. ~18, B. ~68, C. ~368, D. ~680
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main characteristic that distinguishes vipers from most other snakes? Options: A. Vipers are highly venomous, B. Vipers lay eggs, C. Vipers give birth to live young, D. Vipers have long, hollow fangs Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary function of the rattle on a rattlesnake's tail? Options: A. To attract prey, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To warn off predators, D. To communicate with other snakes Correct Option: None
Question 3: What unique feature does the spider-tailed horned viper use to lure prey? Options: A. Its bright coloration, B. Its loud rattle, C. Its bulbous tail-tip with long drooping scales, D. Its highly venomous fangs Correct Option: None
Question 4: What type of viper is the bushmaster, and what is its distinctive feature? Options: A. Pit viper, with a heat-sensing pit, B. Rattlesnake, with a loud rattle, C. Horned viper, with a distinctive horn, D. Gaboon viper, with long fangs Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary advantage of the bushmaster's heat-sensing pit? Options: A. It allows the snake to see in the dark, B. It helps the snake regulate its body temperature, C. It enables the snake to detect the heat signature of approaching prey or predators, D. It allows the snake to communicate with other snakes Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which viper is the largest in the world, and what is its average length? Options: A. Bushmaster, over 11 feet, B. African Gaboon viper, over 10 feet, C. Eastern diamondback rattlesnake, over 8 feet, D. Spider-tailed horned viper, over 5 feet Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is unique about the way Gaboon vipers deliver their venom? Options: A. They inject venom quickly and then release their prey, B. They hold onto their prey while the venom takes effect, C. They deliver venom through a series of small bites, D. They use their fangs to inject venom into the air Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do rodents like the desert kangaroo rat evade snakes? Options: A. By playing dead, B. By using their keen sense of smell, C. By stomping their feet, kicking sand, and making acrobatic leaps, D. By using their sharp teeth to defend themselves Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the primary purpose of the hollow, interlocked segments on a rattlesnake's tail? Options: A. To store venom, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To create a loud noise when shaken, D. To attract prey Correct Option: None
Question 10: As of 2021, how many species of viper are there worldwide? Options: A. 100, B. 368, C. 500, D. 1,000 Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to ask about the number of viper species in the world. The correct option in Question 10 (B. 368) also matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. ~368). 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 10

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 2

in the wild. To each their own! That’s why we’re here,

that is integrated with visual information in the optic tectum. This allows the bushmaster to “see”

and strike more accurately. This comes in handy for guarding a nest— unlike most other vipers, 
the bushmaster lays eggs in hollowed out tree buttresses 
or burrows made by other animals. It must be large enough
to defend its nest— in fact, the bushmaster is the
largest viper in the world, reaching lengths of over 11 feet,
with huge fangs and deadly venom. Meanwhile, in the forests 
of sub-Saharan Africa, there’s a shorter, chunkier viper that’s 
even more venomous than the bushmaster. The African Gaboon viper has

kick sand towards them, and evade their strikes 
with acrobatic leaps and powerful kicks— helping them live to guide 
another snake tour.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does viviparity mean?
Options: A. Strongly and brightly colored., B. Gives birth to live young., C. Lays eggs., D. Only gives birth to twins.
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
We get it, not everyone loves snakes. You may not want to encounter one
in the wild. To each their own! That’s why we’re here, 
to take you on a world tour of some of nature’s most incredible snakes
from the safety of your home— and with your very own intrepid guide. All the snakes we’ll be visiting
belong to a group called the vipers. As of 2021, there are 368 species
of viper worldwide. The name comes from the term viviparity,
which means giving birth to live young. Unlike most snakes, which lay eggs, most vipers have eggs 
that hatch inside the mother, who then gives birth 
to up to dozens of tiny snakes. Not glad you’re safe at home yet? Vipers are also often highly venomous, with two hollow fangs that fold flat
to the roofs of their mouths. This allows the fangs to be extra long, unfolding into imposing weapons
when the viper prepares to strike. So how about we pay them a surprise visit? First stop: 
the southeastern United States, where we can hear the viper
before we can see it. The eastern diamondback rattlesnake is
the largest of 36 species of rattlesnake. Rattlesnakes can shake their rattles
up to 90 times per second to warn off predators 
for hours if needed. The rattle consists of hollow, interlocked
segments made of keratin, the same substance that makes
our nails and hair. When the snake shakes its tail,
these segments hit each other, creating a shockingly loud noise. Now onto the mountains of western Iran,
where a spider crawls across a rock, making easy prey for a passing bird—
or not. The spider-tailed horned viper is
perfectly camouflaged, almost invisible, except for its unique bulbous tail-tip
with long drooping scales that look like a leggy spider. Spider-tailed vipers
are only about 50 centimeters long, so they can lure small birds 
within striking range without compromising their ability 
to squeeze into narrow rock crevices. In the rainforests of Latin America 
lives a viper that couldn’t be more different
from the spider-tailed viper— if you can find it. It’s one of the most elusive snakes
in the world: the bushmaster. The bushmaster is a pit viper. Between each eye and nostril,
it has a heat-sensing pit with a membrane covered 
in highly sensitive receptors that respond to temperature changes as small as one one-thousandth 
of a degree Celsius. These pits gather infrared information
that is integrated with visual information in the optic tectum. This allows the bushmaster to “see” 
the heat signature of approaching prey or predators, helping it decide whether or not to strike
and strike more accurately. This comes in handy for guarding a nest— unlike most other vipers, 
the bushmaster lays eggs in hollowed out tree buttresses 
or burrows made by other animals. It must be large enough
to defend its nest— in fact, the bushmaster is the
largest viper in the world, reaching lengths of over 11 feet,
with huge fangs and deadly venom. Meanwhile, in the forests 
of sub-Saharan Africa, there’s a shorter, chunkier viper that’s 
even more venomous than the bushmaster. The African Gaboon viper has 
the longest fangs of any snake— yes, all 3,879 snake species, 
not just vipers— and can deliver 1,000 milligrams
of venom in a single bite— enough to kill ten adult humans. Although deadly, Gaboon vipers 
have a reputation for being slow-moving 
and placid creatures. When they do strike, they hold onto their 
rodent prey while the venom takes effect, then quickly swallow it down. At this point, you may be worrying
about our guide— but never fear, rodents like our little desert 
kangaroo rat have their own skills to evade the serpent’s tooth. They stomp their feet at rattlesnakes,
kick sand towards them, and evade their strikes 
with acrobatic leaps and powerful kicks— helping them live to guide 
another snake tour.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the longest viper in the world?
Options: A. South American Bushmaster., B. African Gaboon viper., C. Iranian spider-tailed viper., D. Eastern diamondback rattlesnake
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main characteristic that distinguishes vipers from most other snakes? Options: A. Vipers are highly venomous, B. Vipers lay eggs, C. Vipers give birth to live young, D. Vipers have long, hollow fangs Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary function of the rattle on a rattlesnake's tail? Options: A. To attract prey, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To warn off predators, D. To communicate with other snakes Correct Option: None
Question 3: What unique feature does the spider-tailed horned viper use to lure prey? Options: A. Its bright coloration, B. Its loud rattle, C. Its bulbous tail-tip with long drooping scales, D. Its highly venomous fangs Correct Option: None
Question 4: What type of viper is the bushmaster, and what is its distinctive feature? Options: A. Pit viper, with a heat-sensing pit, B. Rattlesnake, with a loud rattle, C. Horned viper, with a distinctive horn, D. Gaboon viper, with long fangs Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary advantage of the bushmaster's heat-sensing pit? Options: A. It allows the snake to see in the dark, B. It helps the snake regulate its body temperature, C. It enables the snake to detect the heat signature of approaching prey or predators, D. It allows the snake to communicate with other snakes Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which viper is the largest in the world, and what is its average length? Options: A. Bushmaster, over 11 feet, B. African Gaboon viper, over 10 feet, C. Eastern diamondback rattlesnake, over 8 feet, D. Spider-tailed horned viper, over 5 feet Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is unique about the way Gaboon vipers deliver their venom? Options: A. They inject venom quickly and then release their prey, B. They hold onto their prey while the venom takes effect, C. They deliver venom through a series of small bites, D. They use their fangs to inject venom into the air Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do rodents like the desert kangaroo rat evade snakes? Options: A. By playing dead, B. By using their keen sense of smell, C. By stomping their feet, kicking sand, and making acrobatic leaps, D. By using their sharp teeth to defend themselves Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the primary purpose of the hollow, interlocked segments on a rattlesnake's tail? Options: A. To store venom, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To create a loud noise when shaken, D. To attract prey Correct Option: None
Question 10: As of 2021, how many species of viper are there worldwide? Options: A. 100, B. 368, C. 500, D. 1,000 Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: Which viper is the largest in the world, and what is its average length? Options: A. Bushmaster, over 11 feet, B. African Gaboon viper, over 10 feet, C. Eastern diamondback rattlesnake, over 8 feet, D. Spider-tailed horned viper, over 5 feet.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (identifying the longest viper in the world) and content (mentioning the bushmaster as the correct answer). Although the options are not identical, they both convey the same information.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 4

**Transcript**:
We get it, not everyone loves snakes. You may not want to encounter one
in the wild. To each their own! That’s why we’re here, 
to take you on a world tour of some of nature’s most incredible snakes
from the safety of your home— and with your very own intrepid guide. All the snakes we’ll be visiting
belong to a group called the vipers. As of 2021, there are 368 species
of viper worldwide. The name comes from the term viviparity,
which means giving birth to live young. Unlike most snakes, which lay eggs, most vipers have eggs 
that hatch inside the mother, who then gives birth 
to up to dozens of tiny snakes. Not glad you’re safe at home yet? Vipers are also often highly venomous, with two hollow fangs that fold flat
to the roofs of their mouths. This allows the fangs to be extra long, unfolding into imposing weapons
when the viper prepares to strike. So how about we pay them a surprise visit? First stop: 
the southeastern United States, where we can hear the viper
before we can see it. The eastern diamondback rattlesnake is
the largest of 36 species of rattlesnake. Rattlesnakes can shake their rattles
up to 90 times per second to warn off predators 
for hours if needed. The rattle consists of hollow, interlocked
segments made of keratin, the same substance that makes
our nails and hair. When the snake shakes its tail,
these segments hit each other, creating a shockingly loud noise. Now onto the mountains of western Iran,
where a spider crawls across a rock, making easy prey for a passing bird—
or not. The spider-tailed horned viper is
perfectly camouflaged, almost invisible, except for its unique bulbous tail-tip
with long drooping scales that look like a leggy spider. Spider-tailed vipers
are only about 50 centimeters long, so they can lure small birds 
within striking range without compromising their ability 
to squeeze into narrow rock crevices. In the rainforests of Latin America 
lives a viper that couldn’t be more different
from the spider-tailed viper— if you can find it. It’s one of the most elusive snakes
in the world: the bushmaster. The bushmaster is a pit viper. Between each eye and nostril,
it has a heat-sensing pit with a membrane covered 
in highly sensitive receptors that respond to temperature changes as small as one one-thousandth 
of a degree Celsius. These pits gather infrared information
that is integrated with visual information in the optic tectum. This allows the bushmaster to “see” 
the heat signature of approaching prey or predators, helping it decide whether or not to strike
and strike more accurately. This comes in handy for guarding a nest— unlike most other vipers, 
the bushmaster lays eggs in hollowed out tree buttresses 
or burrows made by other animals. It must be large enough
to defend its nest— in fact, the bushmaster is the
largest viper in the world, reaching lengths of over 11 feet,
with huge fangs and deadly venom. Meanwhile, in the forests 
of sub-Saharan Africa, there’s a shorter, chunkier viper that’s 
even more venomous than the bushmaster. The African Gaboon viper has 
the longest fangs of any snake— yes, all 3,879 snake species, 
not just vipers— and can deliver 1,000 milligrams
of venom in a single bite— enough to kill ten adult humans. Although deadly, Gaboon vipers 
have a reputation for being slow-moving 
and placid creatures. When they do strike, they hold onto their 
rodent prey while the venom takes effect, then quickly swallow it down. At this point, you may be worrying
about our guide— but never fear, rodents like our little desert 
kangaroo rat have their own skills to evade the serpent’s tooth. They stomp their feet at rattlesnakes,
kick sand towards them, and evade their strikes 
with acrobatic leaps and powerful kicks— helping them live to guide 
another snake tour.

in the wild. To each their own! That’s why we’re here, 
to take you on a world tour of some of nature’s most incredible snakes
from the safety of your home— and with your very own intrepid guide. All the snakes we’ll be visiting
belong to a group called the vipers. As of 2021, there are 368 species

which means giving birth to live young. Unlike most snakes, which lay eggs, most vipers have eggs 
that hatch inside the mother, who then gives birth 
to up to dozens of tiny snakes. Not glad you’re safe at home yet? Vipers are also often highly venomous, with two hollow fangs that fold flat
