If the number of matter cubes is greater than the number of antimatter cubes., D. If the number of antimatter cubes is greater than the number of matter cubes. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the analogy used to describe the process of adding nestled pairs? Options: A. A Russian doll of fundamental particles., B. A game of cosmic chess., C. A simulation of annihilations., D. A map of the final set to the original circle. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the significance of the sum never hitting 0 for a matter cube? Options: A. It indicates that the cube will be annihilated., B. It indicates that the cube will survive., C. It indicates that the cube is not part of a pair., D. It indicates that the cube is part of a pair. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the outcome for a matter cube when its sum eventually hits 0? Options: A. It will be annihilated., B. It will survive., C. It will become part of a new pair., D. It will be buffered from antimatter. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the final outcome for the particle or cube that chooses a safe spot? Options: A. It will be annihilated., B. It will survive and become part of a new pair., C. It will be the last particle standing., D. It will be buffered from antimatter. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s moments after the Big Bang
and... wow, you’re still reeling. You’re a particle of matter, 
amidst a chaotic stew of forces, fusion, and annihilation. If you’re lucky
and avoid being destroyed by antimatter, you'll be the seed of a future galaxy. You gravitate towards a ring of particles
that have devised a game. A friendly gluon explains: there are an equal number of matter 
and antimatter particles. At the blow of a cosmic whistle, every particle of matter with a particle 
of antimatter to its immediate right will merge with that anitparticle
to—poof!— both annihilate. The circle will tighten 
to make a smaller circle, and the process will repeat 
until just one particle of matter remains. They’d been waiting for someone like you,
as with a perfectly balanced setup, no one would be left in the end. As guest of honor, they’ll let you choose 
where to insert yourself into the ring. What spot should you choose to make sure
you’re the last particle standing? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Explanation in 3 Explanation in 2 Explanation in 1 A general strategy can’t rely on knowing
what the circle looks like. But we can rely on how it should end: 
with you as the last particle standing. Let's start there and work backwards. Just before this, there were also 
some matter/antimatter pairs. Here’s 3 for the sake of example. This right away suggests a strategy. You can simulate annihilations 
in any circle by marking all pairs 
of adjacent particles, then the newly adjacent pairs, and so on,
to reach this final set. If you map them back 
to the original circle, standing to the immediate left 
of those final matter particles or the immediate right 
of final antiparticles means you’ll reach this endgame state 
and survive. So here are the safe spots 
in all three given circles. You find a good position and experience
the bittersweet radiance of your new friends pairing off
and becoming pure energy. You’re soon left alone. But wait a minute! Today’s the big day. You’re an intelligent creature of matter
amidst a chaotic crowd of alien races. Every hundred million years, sentient species of the galaxy 
send emissaries to the core to pay tribute to the galactic seed 
you’re all descended from. Each of the 27,182 attendees has brought a cube of matter 
and a cube of antimatter. Except you: you’ve been chosen 
to represent your famed ancestor and reenact its moment of choice. Everyone places their matter 
and antimatter cubes in a ring. Your job: pick a spot to stand 
where you won’t be annihilated. The ring is too large to simulate
annihilations like before, but you have a programmable device
you can point at spots between cubes. The device can detect the full sequence
of cubes around the circle, count cubes of each type,
perform arithmetic, and carry out simple logical commands. How do you program your device 
to identify safe spots? Pause to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s go back to our earlier approach: running time backwards 
starting from you alone, then a sequence of pairs of cubes. A second step back produces more pairs
nestled between existing cubes. As does the next, and the next,
each adding nestled pairs like a Russian doll 
of fundamental particles. A pair never forms around an existing cube
because only adjacent cubes annihilate. Your survival depends 
on the matter particles to your right buffering you from antimatter. We can mathematically model this idea 
with a sum, starting with your +1. For instance, this would be +1+1-1+1-1. From your perspective, 
no matter how far you look, this sum will be positive. Considering how we introduced pairs, 
this makes sense— each inserted plus was immediately
followed by a minus. If we examine the starting position
of any other matter cube, its sum will eventually hit zero. The moment that happens 
marks its exact annihilation partner. Again, our introduction of pairs 
reflects this; nestled pairs only delay the inevitable
for the outer cubes. We can now program the device. Start a running sum with +1,
representing you, and scan around the circle. For each matter cube, add one, and for each antimatter cube, 
subtract one. If all 54,364 cubes have been scanned without the sum ever hitting 0, that spot is safe. Nothing left to do 
but enjoy the fireworks.

Correct Option: C

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Yes! All three, for sure, will survive., B. Maybe. It depends on the ring pattern., C. Not all three will survive.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the mid-1930s, two familiar spires
towered above the morning fog. Stretching 227 meters into the sky, these 22,000-ton towers would help support
California’s Golden Gate Bridge. But since they were currently
in Pennsylvania, they first had to be dismantled,
packaged, and shipped piece by piece over 4,500 kilometers away. Moving the bridge’s towers 
across a continent was just one of the challenges 
facing Charles Ellis and Joseph Strauss, the project's lead engineers. Even before construction began, 
the pair faced all kinds of opposition. The military feared the bridge 
would make the important harbor an even more vulnerable target. Ferry companies claimed the bridge
would steal their business, and residents wanted to preserve
the area's natural scenery. Worse still, many engineers thought
the project was impossible. The Golden Gate Strait was home 
to 96-kilometer-per-hour winds, swirling tides, an endless blanket of fog, and the earthquake-prone 
San Andreas fault. But Strauss was convinced 
the bridge could be built; and that it would provide 
San Francisco’s commuters more reliable passage to the city. He was, however, a bit out of his depth. Strauss’s initial plans to span the strait
used a cantilever bridge. This kind of bridge consists 
of a single beam anchored at one end and extended horizontally
like a diving board. Since these bridges can only extend so far
before collapsing under their own weight, Strauss’s design used two cantilevers,
linked by a structure in the middle. But Ellis and his colleague Leon Moisseif
convinced Strauss to pursue a different approach:
the suspension bridge. Where a cantilever bridge is supported
from one end a suspension bridge suspends its deck
from cables strung across the gap. The result is a more flexible structure that’s resilient to winds 
and shifting loads. This kind of design had long been used 
for small rope bridges. And in the 1930s, 
advanced steel manufacturing could create cables of bundled wire 
to act as strong steel rope for large-scale construction. At the time, the Golden Gate Bridge was the longest and tallest 
suspension bridge ever attempted, and its design was only possible
due to these innovations. But cables and towers of this size 
could only be built at large steelworks on the country’s east coast. While the recently completed Panama Canal made it possible to ship these components
to California, reassembling the towers on site 
didn’t go quite as smoothly. It was relatively easy to find a stable,
shallow foundation for the north tower. But building the south tower 
essentially required erecting a ten-story building underwater. Since the strait’s depth prevented them
drilling or digging the foundations, bombs were dropped on the ocean floor,
creating openings for pouring concrete. A seawall was built to protect the site
from powerful currents, and workers operated in 20-minute shifts
between tides. The towers had so many compartments
that each worker carried a set of plans to prevent getting lost. And at one point, an earthquake rocked
the south tower nearly 5 meters in each direction. Strauss took worker safety very seriously,
requiring hard hats at all times and stretching a safety net 
below the towers. But not even these precautions 
could prevent an entire scaffolding platform
from falling in 1937, carrying ten workers to their deaths. Once the towers were complete, 
workers spun the cables in place, hung suspenders at 50-foot intervals,
and laid down the concrete roadway. The bridge was finished,
but there was still one more task ahead: painting it. After production, the steel had been 
coated with a reddish paint primer it maintained throughout construction. But the Navy had been pushing hard to paint the bridge 
a tactical black and yellow. Consulting architect Irving Morrow 
actually thought the primer itself paired nicely with the strait’s 
natural backdrop— and he wasn’t alone. Citing numerous letters from locals, Morrow’s 30-page pitch 
to paint the bridge “international orange” beat out the Navy’s plans. And today, this iconic color 
still complements the strait’s blue water, green hills, 
and rolling fog.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these was NOT one of the structural difficulties of building a bridge across the Golden Gate?
Options: A. Impenetrable bedrock, B. Earthquakes, C. Strong winds and tides
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the height of the two towers that would help support California's Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. 100 meters, B. 200 meters, C. 227 meters, D. 300 meters Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why did the military oppose the construction of the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. They thought it would harm the local wildlife, B. They feared it would make the harbor a more vulnerable target, C. They believed it would be too expensive to build, D. They thought it would be an eyesore Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of bridge did Joseph Strauss initially plan to build across the Golden Gate Strait? Options: A. Suspension bridge, B. Cantilever bridge, C. Arch bridge, D. Beam bridge Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the main advantage of a suspension bridge over a cantilever bridge? Options: A. It is less expensive to build, B. It is more aesthetically pleasing, C. It is more flexible and resilient to winds and shifting loads, D. It is easier to maintain Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why did the construction team have to ship the bridge's towers from the east coast to California? Options: A. Because they were too heavy to transport by land, B. Because they were too large to build on-site, C. Because the steelworks on the east coast were the only ones capable of building them, D. Because it was more cost-effective Correct Option: None
Question 6: What innovation made it possible to build large-scale suspension bridges like the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. Advanced concrete manufacturing, B. Advanced steel manufacturing, C. Advanced cable manufacturing, D. Advanced construction techniques Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the main challenge in building the south tower of the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. Finding a stable foundation, B. Building a seawall to protect the site from currents, C. Operating in 20-minute shifts between tides, D. Erecting a ten-story building underwater Correct Option: None
Question 8: What safety precaution did Joseph Strauss require for workers on the bridge? Options: A. Hard hats at all times, B. Safety nets below the towers, C. Regular breaks to rest and rehydrate, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the original color proposed by the Navy for the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. International orange, B. Tactical black and yellow, C. Navy blue, D. Grey Correct Option: None
Question 10: Who convinced the construction team to paint the Golden Gate Bridge "international orange"? Options: A. Joseph Strauss, B. Charles Ellis, C. Irving Morrow, D. Leon Moisseif Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is Question 7: What was the main challenge in building the south tower of the Golden Gate Bridge? 

However, this question does not match the ground truth MCQ. A more suitable match is not present among the provided options as none of the questions directly address the structural difficulties of building a bridge across the Golden Gate Strait.

But if we were to choose an MCQ that somewhat closely matches the ground truth MCQ based on the content, options, and overall intent, I would suggest Question 7 is not the correct choice, instead I would choose Question 3: What type of bridge did Joseph Strauss initially plan to build across the Golden Gate Strait? is not the correct match.

A better match would be Question 4: What is the main advantage of a suspension bridge over a cantilever bridge? This question does not directly address the structural difficulties, but it addresses the advantages of the type of bridge built over the Golden Gate Strait.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the mid-1930s, two familiar spires
towered above the morning fog. Stretching 227 meters into the sky, these 22,000-ton towers would help support
California’s Golden Gate Bridge. But since they were currently
in Pennsylvania, they first had to be dismantled,
packaged, and shipped piece by piece over 4,500 kilometers away. Moving the bridge’s towers 
across a continent was just one of the challenges 
facing Charles Ellis and Joseph Strauss, the project's lead engineers. Even before construction began, 
the pair faced all kinds of opposition. The military feared the bridge 
would make the important harbor an even more vulnerable target. Ferry companies claimed the bridge
would steal their business, and residents wanted to preserve
the area's natural scenery. Worse still, many engineers thought
the project was impossible. The Golden Gate Strait was home 
to 96-kilometer-per-hour winds, swirling tides, an endless blanket of fog, and the earthquake-prone 
San Andreas fault. But Strauss was convinced 
the bridge could be built; and that it would provide 
San Francisco’s commuters more reliable passage to the city. He was, however, a bit out of his depth. Strauss’s initial plans to span the strait
used a cantilever bridge. This kind of bridge consists 
of a single beam anchored at one end and extended horizontally
like a diving board. Since these bridges can only extend so far
before collapsing under their own weight, Strauss’s design used two cantilevers,
linked by a structure in the middle. But Ellis and his colleague Leon Moisseif
convinced Strauss to pursue a different approach:
the suspension bridge. Where a cantilever bridge is supported
from one end a suspension bridge suspends its deck
from cables strung across the gap. The result is a more flexible structure that’s resilient to winds 
and shifting loads. This kind of design had long been used 
for small rope bridges. And in the 1930s, 
advanced steel manufacturing could create cables of bundled wire 
to act as strong steel rope for large-scale construction. At the time, the Golden Gate Bridge was the longest and tallest 
suspension bridge ever attempted, and its design was only possible
due to these innovations. But cables and towers of this size 
could only be built at large steelworks on the country’s east coast. While the recently completed Panama Canal made it possible to ship these components
to California, reassembling the towers on site 
didn’t go quite as smoothly. It was relatively easy to find a stable,
shallow foundation for the north tower. But building the south tower 
essentially required erecting a ten-story building underwater. Since the strait’s depth prevented them
drilling or digging the foundations, bombs were dropped on the ocean floor,
creating openings for pouring concrete. A seawall was built to protect the site
from powerful currents, and workers operated in 20-minute shifts
between tides. The towers had so many compartments
that each worker carried a set of plans to prevent getting lost. And at one point, an earthquake rocked
the south tower nearly 5 meters in each direction. Strauss took worker safety very seriously,
requiring hard hats at all times and stretching a safety net 
below the towers. But not even these precautions 
could prevent an entire scaffolding platform
from falling in 1937, carrying ten workers to their deaths. Once the towers were complete, 
workers spun the cables in place, hung suspenders at 50-foot intervals,
and laid down the concrete roadway. The bridge was finished,
but there was still one more task ahead: painting it. After production, the steel had been 
coated with a reddish paint primer it maintained throughout construction. But the Navy had been pushing hard to paint the bridge 
a tactical black and yellow. Consulting architect Irving Morrow 
actually thought the primer itself paired nicely with the strait’s 
natural backdrop— and he wasn’t alone. Citing numerous letters from locals, Morrow’s 30-page pitch 
to paint the bridge “international orange” beat out the Navy’s plans. And today, this iconic color 
still complements the strait’s blue water, green hills, 
and rolling fog.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these was NOT one of the arguments against the bridge’s construction?
Options: A. Security concerns from the military, B. Ferry companies fearing competition, C. Disruption of wildlife habitats
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

In the mid-1930s, two familiar spires
towered above the morning fog. Stretching 227 meters into the sky, these 22,000-ton towers would help support
California’s Golden Gate Bridge. But since they were currently
in Pennsylvania, they first had to be dismantled,

the bridge could be built; and that it would provide 
San Francisco’s commuters more reliable passage to the city. He was, however, a bit out of his depth. Strauss’s initial plans to span the strait
used a cantilever bridge. This kind of bridge consists

the suspension bridge. Where a cantilever bridge is supported
from one end a suspension bridge suspends its deck
from cables strung across the gap. The result is a more flexible structure that’s resilient to winds 
and shifting loads. This kind of design had long been used 
for small rope bridges. And in the 1930s, 
advanced steel manufacturing could create cables of bundled wire 
to act as strong steel rope for large-scale construction. At the time, the Golden Gate Bridge was the longest and tallest 
suspension bridge ever attempted, and its design was only possible
due to these innovations. But cables and towers of this size 
could only be built at large steelworks on the country’s east coast. While the recently completed Panama Canal made it possible to ship these components
to California, reassembling the towers on site 
didn’t go quite as smoothly. It was relatively easy to find a stable,
shallow foundation for the north tower. But building the south tower 
essentially required erecting a ten-story building underwater. Since the strait’s depth prevented them
drilling or digging the foundations, bombs were dropped on the ocean floor,
creating openings for pouring concrete. A seawall was built to protect the site
from powerful currents, and workers operated in 20-minute shifts
between tides. The towers had so many compartments
that each worker carried a set of plans to prevent getting lost. And at one point, an earthquake rocked
the south tower nearly 5 meters in each direction. Strauss took worker safety very seriously,
requiring hard hats at all times and stretching a safety net 
below the towers. But not even these precautions 
could prevent an entire scaffolding platform
from falling in 1937, carrying ten workers to their deaths. Once the towers were complete, 
workers spun the cables in place, hung suspenders at 50-foot intervals,
and laid down the concrete roadway. The bridge was finished,
but there was still one more task ahead: painting it. After production, the steel had been

a tactical black and yellow. Consulting architect Irving Morrow 
actually thought the primer itself paired nicely with the strait’s 
natural backdrop— and he wasn’t alone. Citing numerous letters from locals, Morrow’s 30-page pitch 
to paint the bridge “international orange” beat out the Navy’s plans. And today, this iconic color 
still complements the strait’s blue water, green hills, 
and rolling fog.

Options: A. California, B. Pennsylvania, C. New York
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the mid-1930s, two familiar spires
towered above the morning fog. Stretching 227 meters into the sky, these 22,000-ton towers would help support
California’s Golden Gate Bridge. But since they were currently
in Pennsylvania, they first had to be dismantled,
packaged, and shipped piece by piece over 4,500 kilometers away. Moving the bridge’s towers 
across a continent was just one of the challenges 
facing Charles Ellis and Joseph Strauss, the project's lead engineers. Even before construction began,

would make the important harbor an even more vulnerable target. Ferry companies claimed the bridge
would steal their business, and residents wanted to preserve
the area's natural scenery. Worse still, many engineers thought
the project was impossible. The Golden Gate Strait was home 
to 96-kilometer-per-hour winds, swirling tides, an endless blanket of fog, and the earthquake-prone 
San Andreas fault. But Strauss was convinced 
the bridge could be built; and that it would provide 
San Francisco’s commuters more reliable passage to the city. He was, however, a bit out of his depth. Strauss’s initial plans to span the strait
used a cantilever bridge. This kind of bridge consists

linked by a structure in the middle. But Ellis and his colleague Leon Moisseif

the suspension bridge. Where a cantilever bridge is supported
from one end a suspension bridge suspends its deck
from cables strung across the gap. The result is a more flexible structure that’s resilient to winds 
and shifting loads. This kind of design had long been used 
for small rope bridges. And in the 1930s, 
advanced steel manufacturing could create cables of bundled wire 
to act as strong steel rope for large-scale construction. At the time, the Golden Gate Bridge was the longest and tallest 
suspension bridge ever attempted, and its design was only possible
due to these innovations. But cables and towers of this size 
could only be built at large steelworks on the country’s east coast. While the recently completed Panama Canal made it possible to ship these components
to California, reassembling the towers on site 
didn’t go quite as smoothly. It was relatively easy to find a stable,
shallow foundation for the north tower. But building the south tower 
essentially required erecting a ten-story building underwater. Since the strait’s depth prevented them
drilling or digging the foundations, bombs were dropped on the ocean floor,
creating openings for pouring concrete. A seawall was built to protect the site
from powerful currents, and workers operated in 20-minute shifts
between tides. The towers had so many compartments
that each worker carried a set of plans to prevent getting lost. And at one point, an earthquake rocked
the south tower nearly 5 meters in each direction. Strauss took worker safety very seriously,
requiring hard hats at all times and stretching a safety net 
below the towers. But not even these precautions 
could prevent an entire scaffolding platform
from falling in 1937, carrying ten workers to their deaths. Once the towers were complete, 
workers spun the cables in place, hung suspenders at 50-foot intervals,
and laid down the concrete roadway. The bridge was finished,
but there was still one more task ahead: painting it. After production, the steel had been 
coated with a reddish paint primer it maintained throughout construction. But the Navy had been pushing hard to paint the bridge 
a tactical black and yellow. Consulting architect Irving Morrow 
actually thought the primer itself paired nicely with the strait’s 
natural backdrop— and he wasn’t alone. Citing numerous letters from locals, Morrow’s 30-page pitch 
to paint the bridge “international orange” beat out the Navy’s plans. And today, this iconic color 
still complements the strait’s blue water, green hills, 
and rolling fog.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When was the bridge completed?
Options: A. 1937, B. 1929, C. 1943
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the height of the two towers that would help support California's Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. 100 meters, B. 200 meters, C. 227 meters, D. 300 meters Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why did the military oppose the construction of the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. They thought it would harm the local wildlife, B. They feared it would make the harbor a more vulnerable target, C. They believed it would be too expensive to build, D. They thought it would be an eyesore Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of bridge did Joseph Strauss initially plan to build across the Golden Gate Strait? Options: A. Suspension bridge, B. Cantilever bridge, C. Arch bridge, D. Beam bridge Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the main advantage of a suspension bridge over a cantilever bridge? Options: A. It is less expensive to build, B. It is more aesthetically pleasing, C. It is more flexible and resilient to winds and shifting loads, D. It is easier to maintain Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why did the construction team have to ship the bridge's towers from the east coast to California? Options: A. Because they were too heavy to transport by land, B. Because they were too large to build on-site, C. Because the steelworks on the east coast were the only ones capable of building them, D. Because it was more cost-effective Correct Option: None
Question 6: What innovation made it possible to build large-scale suspension bridges like the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. Advanced concrete manufacturing, B. Advanced steel manufacturing, C. Advanced cable manufacturing, D. Advanced construction techniques Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the main challenge in building the south tower of the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. Finding a stable foundation, B. Building a seawall to protect the site from currents, C. Operating in 20-minute shifts between tides, D. Erecting a ten-story building underwater Correct Option: None
Question 8: What safety precaution did Joseph Strauss require for workers on the bridge? Options: A. Hard hats at all times, B. Safety nets below the towers, C. Regular breaks to rest and rehydrate, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the original color proposed by the Navy for the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. International orange, B. Tactical black and yellow, C. Navy blue, D. Grey Correct Option: None
Question 10: Who convinced the construction team to paint the Golden Gate Bridge "international orange"? Options: A. Joseph Strauss, B. Charles Ellis, C. Irving Morrow, D. Leon Moisseif Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about the completion year of the bridge, while the generated MCQs cover various other topics related to the bridge's construction, design, and history.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the topic of the bridge's construction timeline, I would suggest Question 8, which mentions a specific event (the scaffolding platform falling) that occurred in 1937, the same year the bridge was completed. Nevertheless, this question does not directly ask about the completion year of the bridge.

Therefore, I must conclude that none of the generated MCQs closely match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hera, queen of the gods, 
was on the edge of her throne. A mountain nymph named Echo, 
renowned for her charm and chatter, was regaling her with a sensational story. But what Hera didn’t know 
was that Echo was merely distracting her while her husband, Zeus, was frolicking about 
with the other nymphs. Unfortunately for Echo, Zeus got sloppy,
and Hera realized what was going on. Enraged by Echo’s duplicity— and powerless to stop 
her husband’s adultery— Hera decided to silence
the nymph for good. From then on, Echo could no longer
enrapture listeners with her stories; she could only repeat the last words
another said. As her conversations became dull 
and her company undesirable, Echo grew dispirited. One day, while Echo was drifting
through the woods, she spotted a young man hunting deer. It was Narcissus, the stunningly beautiful
son of a river god and water nymph. After his birth, a seer had given 
his mother a cryptic prophecy: Narcissus would live a long life—
but only if he never really knew himself. No one was sure exactly 
what to make of this. And, in the meantime,
Narcissus grew into a proud youth. His good looks attracted many admirers. But he preferred to amble through life
on his own and left a trail of broken hearts 
in his wake. Seeing Narcissus there, 
Echo was filled with longing. Unable to initiate a conversation,
she walked after him. Soon, Narcissus heard a rustle, 
and called out, “Who goes there? Who are you?” Echo revealed herself,
but only repeated the word “you,” making her tone as endearing as possible
as she went to hold him. Agitated, Narcissus said, 
“Let me go, I can’t stay.” Echo could only counter 
with a plea for him to do so. Freeing himself from her embrace,
Narcissus snapped, “I’d rather die than have you love me!” To which Echo could only cry,
“Love me... love me.” Narcissus told Echo once more 
to leave him alone, then faded from her gaze. Echo wandered to a cave. And gradually, her heart grew heavy
and her body frail until all that was left of her 
was her voice, which the wind carried to vast,
empty places. Forever after, it could be heard 
reverberating through hollow caves and rebounding across lonely clearings. But this wasn’t even the first time
heartbreak over Narcissus had proven fatal. A young man named Ameinias had also been
cruelly rejected by Narcissus. Before his death, he prayed to Nemesis,
the goddess of revenge, that Narcissus would also one day
know the pain of love. She heard Ameinias’ pleas and, 
upon witnessing Echo’s fate, decided that it would be 
the final affront. It was time for retribution. So, Nemesis set Narcissus 
towards a clear, glassy pool. As he bent towards the water to drink, he caught sight
of a hauntingly beautiful young man. Never before had Narcissus 
seen himself with such clarity. He spent the day acquainting himself
with every glinting angle and glowing curl then passed the evening 
gazing at his reflection by moonlight and sleeping with his fingers
grazing the water. Days wore on, and Narcissus never parted
from his one true love. When he reached out, 
his double reached for him; and when he leaned in to bestow a kiss,
he also tilted his face. But when he tried to hold 
the bewitching figure, it disappeared. At last, Narcissus knew the agony
of unrequited love. Eating and drinking nothing, 
Narcissus too wasted away. His neck ached from bending over the lake,
and his legs became rooted to the grass. When the wood nymphs finally passed by, all that was left of him 
was a white and yellow flower bending towards its reflection. From then on, it was known as narcissus.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: While Zeus frolicked with other nymphs, Echo distracted Hera by:
Options: A. Doing dances, B. Playing tricks, C. Telling stories, D. Swimming
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was distracting Hera with a sensational story while Zeus was frolicking with other nymphs? Options: A. A mountain nymph named Ameinias, B. A river god, C. A mountain nymph named Echo, D. Nemesis, the goddess of revenge Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the punishment given to Echo by Hera? Options: A. She was banished from Mount Olympus, B. She was turned into a flower, C. She could only repeat the last words another said, D. She was forced to live in a cave Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the cryptic prophecy given to Narcissus' mother by a seer? Options: A. Narcissus would live a short life if he never really knew himself, B. Narcissus would live a long life if he never really knew himself, C. Narcissus would be a great warrior, D. Narcissus would be a great leader Correct Option: None
Question 4: Why did Narcissus reject Echo's love? Options: A. He was already in love with someone else, B. He was not attracted to her, C. He preferred to be alone, D. He was afraid of Hera's wrath Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happened to Echo after being rejected by Narcissus? Options: A. She was turned into a flower, B. She was banished from the forest, C. Her heart grew heavy and her body frail until only her voice remained, D. She fell in love with someone else Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who prayed to Nemesis, the goddess of revenge, to punish Narcissus? Options: A. Echo, B. Ameinias, C. Hera, D. Zeus Correct Option: None
Question 7: How did Nemesis punish Narcissus? Options: A. She turned him into a flower, B. She made him fall in love with his own reflection, C. She banished him from the forest, D. She took away his good looks Correct Option: None
Question 8: What happened to Narcissus as he gazed at his reflection? Options: A. He became more confident and proud, B. He fell deeply in love with himself, C. He became angry and frustrated, D. He was unaffected Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the final outcome for Narcissus? Options: A. He lived happily ever after with his reflection, B. He was turned into a god, C. He wasted away and was turned into a flower, D. He was banished from the forest Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the name of the flower that Narcissus was turned into? Options: A. Daffodil, B. Sunflower, C. Narcissus, D. Lily Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1, but it does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. However, Question 1 does mention Echo distracting Hera, which is the main intent of the ground truth MCQ.

A more suitable generated MCQ would be one that asks how Echo distracted Hera, rather than who distracted Hera. Unfortunately, such a question does not exist among the provided generated MCQs.

However, if we had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the provided options, it would be Question 1.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 4

gazing at his reflection by moonlight and sleeping with his fingers
grazing the water. Days wore on, and Narcissus never parted
from his one true love. When he reached out, 
his double reached for him; and when he leaned in to bestow a kiss,
he also tilted his face. But when he tried to hold 
the bewitching figure, it disappeared. At last, Narcissus knew the agony
of unrequited love. Eating and drinking nothing, 
Narcissus too wasted away. His neck ached from bending over the lake,
and his legs became rooted to the grass. When the wood nymphs finally passed by, all that was left of him 
was a white and yellow flower bending towards its reflection. From then on, it was known as narcissus.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which Goddess selected a punishment for Narcissus?
Options: A. Hera, B. Nemesis, C. Hecate, D. Aphrodite
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hera, queen of the gods, 
was on the edge of her throne. A mountain nymph named Echo, 
renowned for her charm and chatter, was regaling her with a sensational story. But what Hera didn’t know 
was that Echo was merely distracting her while her husband, Zeus, was frolicking about 
with the other nymphs. Unfortunately for Echo, Zeus got sloppy,
and Hera realized what was going on. Enraged by Echo’s duplicity— and powerless to stop 
her husband’s adultery— Hera decided to silence
the nymph for good. From then on, Echo could no longer
enrapture listeners with her stories; she could only repeat the last words
another said. As her conversations became dull 
and her company undesirable, Echo grew dispirited. One day, while Echo was drifting
through the woods, she spotted a young man hunting deer. It was Narcissus, the stunningly beautiful
son of a river god and water nymph. After his birth, a seer had given 
his mother a cryptic prophecy: Narcissus would live a long life—
but only if he never really knew himself. No one was sure exactly 
what to make of this. And, in the meantime,
Narcissus grew into a proud youth. His good looks attracted many admirers. But he preferred to amble through life
on his own and left a trail of broken hearts 
in his wake. Seeing Narcissus there, 
Echo was filled with longing. Unable to initiate a conversation,
she walked after him. Soon, Narcissus heard a rustle, 
and called out, “Who goes there? Who are you?” Echo revealed herself,
but only repeated the word “you,” making her tone as endearing as possible
as she went to hold him. Agitated, Narcissus said, 
“Let me go, I can’t stay.” Echo could only counter 
with a plea for him to do so. Freeing himself from her embrace,
Narcissus snapped, “I’d rather die than have you love me!” To which Echo could only cry,
“Love me... love me.” Narcissus told Echo once more 
to leave him alone, then faded from her gaze. Echo wandered to a cave. And gradually, her heart grew heavy
and her body frail until all that was left of her 
was her voice, which the wind carried to vast,
empty places. Forever after, it could be heard 
reverberating through hollow caves and rebounding across lonely clearings. But this wasn’t even the first time
heartbreak over Narcissus had proven fatal. A young man named Ameinias had also been
cruelly rejected by Narcissus. Before his death, he prayed to Nemesis,
the goddess of revenge, that Narcissus would also one day
know the pain of love. She heard Ameinias’ pleas and, 
upon witnessing Echo’s fate, decided that it would be 
the final affront. It was time for retribution. So, Nemesis set Narcissus 
towards a clear, glassy pool. As he bent towards the water to drink, he caught sight
of a hauntingly beautiful young man. Never before had Narcissus 
seen himself with such clarity. He spent the day acquainting himself
with every glinting angle and glowing curl then passed the evening 
gazing at his reflection by moonlight and sleeping with his fingers
grazing the water. Days wore on, and Narcissus never parted
from his one true love. When he reached out, 
his double reached for him; and when he leaned in to bestow a kiss,
he also tilted his face. But when he tried to hold 
the bewitching figure, it disappeared. At last, Narcissus knew the agony
of unrequited love. Eating and drinking nothing, 
Narcissus too wasted away. His neck ached from bending over the lake,
and his legs became rooted to the grass. When the wood nymphs finally passed by, all that was left of him 
was a white and yellow flower bending towards its reflection. From then on, it was known as narcissus.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Eventually, Narcissus was transformed into:
Options: A. A flower, B. A tree, C. A river, D. An echo
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On April 12, 1961,
Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin piloted a 2,400 kilogram spacecraft 
in humanity’s first manned space flight. One week later, Bell Aerosystems debuted
another advancement in aviation: the gas-powered rocket pack. Capable of flying 35 meters 
in just 13 seconds, the rocket pack thrilled onlookers. But the device’s engineers
were less enthused. Despite years of cutting-edge work, they knew this short flight was all
the rocket pack could muster. So why was a massive spacecraft easier
to send flying than a single pilot? According to Newton's laws of motion, the physics behind flight are
actually quite simple. All you need is a powerful enough
upward force to counteract the downward force 
of gravity. And since objects with more mass
experience stronger gravitational forces, lighter objects should be easier
to get off the ground. However, modern jet engines,
our primary tool for flight, actually get more efficient
the larger they are. Jet engines work by sucking in huge
volumes of air, and then expelling that air
as quickly as possible. While most of this actually bypasses
the inner machinery, it still contributes to a huge portion
of the engine's thrust. But the air that does enter 
the engine’s core gets compressed by a series of tightly packed blades. That compressed air then enters
the combustion chamber, where it is injected with jet fuel
and ignited. The heat causes the compressed air 
to rapidly expand, bursting out of the exhaust 
and propelling the engine forward. As air leaves the engine it also turns 
a turbine embedded in the exhaust nozzle. This turbine powers the fan
and the compressor blades, creating a cycle that maintains thrust
for as long as there’s fuel to burn. The more air an engine can take in and 
expel the more thrust it can produce. On a modern jet, the diameter 
of a frontal fan is larger than a truck. And even spinning 
at relatively low speeds, these engines produce more than enough
thrust to maintain the necessary speed for flying a passenger aircraft. But smaller engines simply can’t 
take in this much air. For most of the 20th century,
engineers couldn’t produce an engine small and light enough 
for an individual to wear, yet powerful enough to lift itself 
alongside its pilot and fuel. Designs could only carry enough fuel
for 30 seconds of flight, and when airborne, 
the powerful thrust in a single direction made jetpacks difficult
and dangerous to control. But the new millennium brought advances
in materials, manufacturing, and computing technology, including systems which could manage
fuel injection with incredible precision. Together, these dramatically improved 
the fuel efficiency and power-to-weight ratio of jet engines. By 2016, micro-engines the size 
of a coffee can and weighing less than 2kg could achieve 220 Newtons of force. This was when an English engineer
named Richard Browning saw the opportunity to create 
a new kind of lightweight jetpack. In addition to a single engine
strapped to the back, this so-called Jet Suit involved a pair
of micro-engines on each arm to split and balance the thrust. Working with the back engine,
these provided three-points of stability, which some pilots describe as being 
akin to comfortably leaning on crutches while a friend supports your back. It may seem complicated to manage
all these engines at once, but many pilots master 
it in less than a day with the help of another 
advanced computer system— their brain. Various brain regions 
and multiple sensory systems perfectly calibrate our sense of balance 
and spatial orientation, helping pilots smoothly
direct their flights. Slight movements of the arms allow
operators to increase and decrease lift, quickly turn in mid-air, 
or glide forward for up to 5 minutes. This technology is still fairly new, and without major advances
in fuel efficiency and engine technology, don’t expect to have a jetpack
of your own any time soon. But if reaching for the sky
already got us this far, who knows where we'll fly next?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To fly, all you need is a powerful upward force to counteract the downward force of _________.
Options: A. Mass, B. Gravity, C. Resistance, D. Air
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who piloted the first manned space flight on April 12, 1961? Options: A. Yuri Gagarin, B. Richard Browning, C. Neil Armstrong, D. Buzz Aldrin Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to Newton's laws of motion, what is required to counteract the downward force of gravity? Options: A. A powerful enough downward force, B. A powerful enough upward force, C. A powerful enough horizontal force, D. A powerful enough diagonal force Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why do modern jet engines become more efficient as they increase in size? Options: A. They can carry more fuel, B. They can take in and expel more air, C. They can fly higher, D. They can fly faster Correct Option: None
Question 4: What powers the fan and compressor blades in a jet engine? Options: A. The turbine embedded in the exhaust nozzle, B. The combustion chamber, C. The inner machinery, D. The frontal fan Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was a major limitation of early jetpack designs? Options: A. They were too heavy, B. They were too expensive, C. They could only carry enough fuel for 30 seconds of flight, D. They were too complicated to control Correct Option: None
Question 6: What advances in technology led to the development of more efficient and powerful jet engines? Options: A. Advances in materials, manufacturing, and computing technology, B. Advances in fuel injection and combustion chamber design, C. Advances in turbine and compressor blade design, D. Advances in frontal fan and exhaust nozzle design Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the English engineer who developed the Jet Suit? Options: A. Richard Browning, B. Yuri Gagarin, C. Neil Armstrong, D. Buzz Aldrin Correct Option: None
Question 8: How does the Jet Suit achieve stability and balance? Options: A. With a single engine strapped to the back, B. With a pair of micro-engines on each arm and a single engine on the back, C. With a pair of micro-engines on each leg and a single engine on the back, D. With a single engine on each arm and a pair of micro-engines on the back Correct Option: None
Question 9: What allows pilots to smoothly direct their flights and maintain balance and spatial orientation? Options: A. The Jet Suit's computer system, B. The pilot's brain and sensory systems, C. The jetpack's fuel injection system, D. The jetpack's combustion chamber Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is a current limitation of jetpack technology? Options: A. It is too expensive, B. It is too complicated to control, C. It requires major advances in fuel efficiency and engine technology, D. It is too heavy Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, as it also references Newton's laws of motion and the need to counteract the downward force of gravity. The correct option in Question 2 (B. A powerful enough upward force) directly matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, which states that all you need to fly is a powerful upward force to counteract the downward force of gravity.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

of your own any time soon. But if reaching for the sky
already got us this far, who knows where we'll fly next?

Question: What happens to the air in a jet-engine?
Options: A. It by-passes the turbine, B. It gets compressed, C. It gets cooled and expelled, D. It gets injected with fuel, E. Both b and d are correct
Correct Option: E

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What made engines unfeasible and inefficient for jet-packs in the 20th century?
Options: A. They couldn’t suck in enough air, B. They took in too much air, C. They were not small or light enough, D. They blew up after 30 seconds, E. Both a and c are correct
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who piloted the first manned space flight on April 12, 1961? Options: A. Yuri Gagarin, B. Richard Browning, C. Neil Armstrong, D. Buzz Aldrin Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to Newton's laws of motion, what is required to counteract the downward force of gravity? Options: A. A powerful enough downward force, B. A powerful enough upward force, C. A powerful enough horizontal force, D. A powerful enough diagonal force Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why do modern jet engines become more efficient as they increase in size? Options: A. They can carry more fuel, B. They can take in and expel more air, C. They can fly higher, D. They can fly faster Correct Option: None
Question 4: What powers the fan and compressor blades in a jet engine? Options: A. The turbine embedded in the exhaust nozzle, B. The combustion chamber, C. The inner machinery, D. The frontal fan Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was a major limitation of early jetpack designs? Options: A. They were too heavy, B. They were too expensive, C. They could only carry enough fuel for 30 seconds of flight, D. They were too complicated to control Correct Option: None
Question 6: What advances in technology led to the development of more efficient and powerful jet engines? Options: A. Advances in materials, manufacturing, and computing technology, B. Advances in fuel injection and combustion chamber design, C. Advances in turbine and compressor blade design, D. Advances in frontal fan and exhaust nozzle design Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the English engineer who developed the Jet Suit? Options: A. Richard Browning, B. Yuri Gagarin, C. Neil Armstrong, D. Buzz Aldrin Correct Option: None
Question 8: How does the Jet Suit achieve stability and balance? Options: A. With a single engine strapped to the back, B. With a pair of micro-engines on each arm and a single engine on the back, C. With a pair of micro-engines on each leg and a single engine on the back, D. With a single engine on each arm and a pair of micro-engines on the back Correct Option: None
Question 9: What allows pilots to smoothly direct their flights and maintain balance and spatial orientation? Options: A. The Jet Suit's computer system, B. The pilot's brain and sensory systems, C. The jetpack's fuel injection system, D. The jetpack's combustion chamber Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is a current limitation of jetpack technology? Options: A. It is too expensive, B. It is too complicated to control, C. It requires major advances in fuel efficiency and engine technology, D. It is too heavy Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What was a major limitation of early jetpack designs? Options: A. They were too heavy, B. They were too expensive, C. They could only carry enough fuel for 30 seconds of flight, D. They were too complicated to control.

However, the correct answer for the ground truth MCQ is "E. Both a and c are correct", which indicates that the engines were not small or light enough and couldn't suck in enough air. Question 5 only addresses one part of the correct answer. 

A more suitable match would be a question that addresses both limitations of the engines. Unfortunately, there isn't a generated MCQ that perfectly matches the ground truth MCQ. But among the given options, Question 5 is the closest match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On April 12, 1961,
Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin piloted a 2,400 kilogram spacecraft 
in humanity’s first manned space flight. One week later, Bell Aerosystems debuted
another advancement in aviation: the gas-powered rocket pack. Capable of flying 35 meters 
in just 13 seconds, the rocket pack thrilled onlookers. But the device’s engineers
were less enthused. Despite years of cutting-edge work, they knew this short flight was all
the rocket pack could muster. So why was a massive spacecraft easier
to send flying than a single pilot? According to Newton's laws of motion, the physics behind flight are
actually quite simple. All you need is a powerful enough
upward force to counteract the downward force 
of gravity. And since objects with more mass
experience stronger gravitational forces, lighter objects should be easier
to get off the ground. However, modern jet engines,
our primary tool for flight, actually get more efficient
the larger they are. Jet engines work by sucking in huge
volumes of air, and then expelling that air
as quickly as possible. While most of this actually bypasses
the inner machinery, it still contributes to a huge portion
of the engine's thrust. But the air that does enter 
the engine’s core gets compressed by a series of tightly packed blades. That compressed air then enters
the combustion chamber, where it is injected with jet fuel
and ignited. The heat causes the compressed air 
to rapidly expand, bursting out of the exhaust 
and propelling the engine forward. As air leaves the engine it also turns 
a turbine embedded in the exhaust nozzle. This turbine powers the fan
and the compressor blades, creating a cycle that maintains thrust
for as long as there’s fuel to burn. The more air an engine can take in and 
expel the more thrust it can produce. On a modern jet, the diameter 
of a frontal fan is larger than a truck. And even spinning 
at relatively low speeds, these engines produce more than enough
thrust to maintain the necessary speed for flying a passenger aircraft. But smaller engines simply can’t 
take in this much air. For most of the 20th century,
engineers couldn’t produce an engine small and light enough 
for an individual to wear, yet powerful enough to lift itself 
alongside its pilot and fuel. Designs could only carry enough fuel
for 30 seconds of flight, and when airborne, 
the powerful thrust in a single direction made jetpacks difficult
and dangerous to control. But the new millennium brought advances
in materials, manufacturing, and computing technology, including systems which could manage
fuel injection with incredible precision. Together, these dramatically improved 
the fuel efficiency and power-to-weight ratio of jet engines. By 2016, micro-engines the size 
of a coffee can and weighing less than 2kg could achieve 220 Newtons of force. This was when an English engineer
named Richard Browning saw the opportunity to create 
a new kind of lightweight jetpack. In addition to a single engine
strapped to the back, this so-called Jet Suit involved a pair
of micro-engines on each arm to split and balance the thrust. Working with the back engine,
these provided three-points of stability, which some pilots describe as being 
akin to comfortably leaning on crutches while a friend supports your back. It may seem complicated to manage
all these engines at once, but many pilots master 
it in less than a day with the help of another 
advanced computer system— their brain. Various brain regions 
and multiple sensory systems perfectly calibrate our sense of balance 
and spatial orientation, helping pilots smoothly
direct their flights. Slight movements of the arms allow
operators to increase and decrease lift, quickly turn in mid-air, 
or glide forward for up to 5 minutes. This technology is still fairly new, and without major advances
in fuel efficiency and engine technology, don’t expect to have a jetpack
of your own any time soon. But if reaching for the sky
already got us this far, who knows where we'll fly next?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In 2016 Micro-jet engines weighing just 2kg were used in a new design of jet-pack designed as a wearable suit. How much thrust could each one achieve?
Options: A. 22kg (approx. 220 Newton’s), B. 42kg (approx. 420 Newton’s), C. 12kg (approx. 120 Newton’s), D. 92kg (approx. 920 Newton’s)
Correct Option: A

Question 6: What advances in technology led to the development of more efficient and powerful jet engines? Options: A. Advances in materials, manufacturing, and computing technology, B. Advances in fuel injection and combustion chamber design, C. Advances in turbine and compressor blade design, D. Advances in frontal fan and exhaust nozzle design Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the English engineer who developed the Jet Suit? Options: A. Richard Browning, B. Yuri Gagarin, C. Neil Armstrong, D. Buzz Aldrin Correct Option: None
Question 8: How does the Jet Suit achieve stability and balance? Options: A. With a single engine strapped to the back, B. With a pair of micro-engines on each arm and a single engine on the back, C. With a pair of micro-engines on each leg and a single engine on the back, D. With a single engine on each arm and a pair of micro-engines on the back Correct Option: None
Question 9: What allows pilots to smoothly direct their flights and maintain balance and spatial orientation? Options: A. The Jet Suit's computer system, B. The pilot's brain and sensory systems, C. The jetpack's fuel injection system, D. The jetpack's combustion chamber Correct Option: None

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The closest generated MCQ is Question 6, which mentions advances in technology that led to the development of more efficient and powerful jet engines. However, it does not specifically mention the thrust achieved by these engines.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On April 12, 1961,
Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin piloted a 2,400 kilogram spacecraft 
in humanity’s first manned space flight. One week later, Bell Aerosystems debuted
another advancement in aviation: the gas-powered rocket pack. Capable of flying 35 meters 
in just 13 seconds, the rocket pack thrilled onlookers. But the device’s engineers
were less enthused. Despite years of cutting-edge work, they knew this short flight was all
the rocket pack could muster. So why was a massive spacecraft easier
to send flying than a single pilot? According to Newton's laws of motion, the physics behind flight are
actually quite simple. All you need is a powerful enough
upward force to counteract the downward force 
of gravity. And since objects with more mass
experience stronger gravitational forces, lighter objects should be easier
to get off the ground. However, modern jet engines,
our primary tool for flight, actually get more efficient
the larger they are. Jet engines work by sucking in huge
volumes of air, and then expelling that air
as quickly as possible. While most of this actually bypasses
the inner machinery, it still contributes to a huge portion
of the engine's thrust. But the air that does enter 
the engine’s core gets compressed by a series of tightly packed blades. That compressed air then enters
the combustion chamber, where it is injected with jet fuel
and ignited. The heat causes the compressed air 
to rapidly expand, bursting out of the exhaust 
and propelling the engine forward. As air leaves the engine it also turns 
a turbine embedded in the exhaust nozzle. This turbine powers the fan
and the compressor blades, creating a cycle that maintains thrust
for as long as there’s fuel to burn. The more air an engine can take in and

of a frontal fan is larger than a truck. And even spinning 
at relatively low speeds, these engines produce more than enough
thrust to maintain the necessary speed for flying a passenger aircraft. But smaller engines simply can’t 
take in this much air. For most of the 20th century,
engineers couldn’t produce an engine small and light enough 
for an individual to wear, yet powerful enough to lift itself 
alongside its pilot and fuel. Designs could only carry enough fuel
for 30 seconds of flight, and when airborne, 
the powerful thrust in a single direction made jetpacks difficult
and dangerous to control. But the new millennium brought advances
in materials, manufacturing, and computing technology, including systems which could manage
fuel injection with incredible precision. Together, these dramatically improved 
the fuel efficiency and power-to-weight ratio of jet engines. By 2016, micro-engines the size 
of a coffee can and weighing less than 2kg could achieve 220 Newtons of force. This was when an English engineer
named Richard Browning saw the opportunity to create 
a new kind of lightweight jetpack. In addition to a single engine
strapped to the back, this so-called Jet Suit involved a pair
of micro-engines on each arm to split and balance the thrust. Working with the back engine,
these provided three-points of stability, which some pilots describe as being 
akin to comfortably leaning on crutches while a friend supports your back. It may seem complicated to manage
all these engines at once, but many pilots master 
it in less than a day with the help of another 
advanced computer system— their brain. Various brain regions 
and multiple sensory systems perfectly calibrate our sense of balance 
and spatial orientation, helping pilots smoothly
direct their flights. Slight movements of the arms allow
operators to increase and decrease lift, quickly turn in mid-air, 
or glide forward for up to 5 minutes. This technology is still fairly new, and without major advances
in fuel efficiency and engine technology, don’t expect to have a jetpack
of your own any time soon. But if reaching for the sky
already got us this far, who knows where we'll fly next?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How is the Gravity Jet-suit controlled?
Options: A. Batteries, B. Computer controlled stability system, C. Brain of the pilot guiding simple arm movements, D. Crutches and a friend pushing your back
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1945, two sculptures meant to represent
the average man and woman in the United States went on exhibit
at the American Museum of Natural History. Based on measurements taken from tens
of thousands of young men and women, they were called Norma and Normman. That same year, a contest launched
to find a living embodiment of Norma. Normal is often used as a synonym
for “typical,” “expected,” or even “correct.” By that logic, most people should fit 
the description of normal. And yet, not one of almost 4,000 women 
who participated in the contest matched Norma,
the supposedly “normal” woman. This puzzle isn’t unique 
to Norma and Normman, either— time and time again, 
so-called normal descriptions of our bodies, minds, and perceptions 
have turned out to match almost no one. And yet, a lot of the world is constructed
around a foundation of normalcy. So what does normal actually mean—
and should we be relying on it so much? In statistics, a normal distribution 
describes  a set of values that fall along a bell curve. The average, or mean, of all the values
is at the very center, and most other values fall 
within the hump of the bell. These curves can be tall, with most values
inside a narrow range, or long and flat, with only a slight bias
towards the average. What makes the distribution normal 
is that it follows this curved shape. Normal doesn’t describe a single data 
point, but a pattern of diversity. Many human traits, like height,
follow a normal distribution. Some people are very tall or very short, but most people fall close 
to the overall average. Outside of statistics, normal
often refers to an average— like the single number pulled 
from the fattest part of the bell curve— that eliminates all the nuance
of the normal distribution. Norma and Norman’s proportions
came from such averages. Applied to individuals, 
whether someone is considered normal usually depends on how closely 
they hew to this average. At best, such definitions of normal 
fail to capture variation. But oftentimes, our calculations of normal
are even more flawed. Take the BMI— or Body Mass Index. BMI is a measure of weight
relative to height, with different ratios 
falling into “underweight,” “normal weight,” “overweight,”
and “obese” ranges. Generally, only BMIs that correspond
to normal weight are considered healthy. But BMI is not always 
an accurate predictor of health, or even of what’s a healthy weight. BMI doesn’t take into account 
body fat percentage, body fat distribution, levels of physical
activity, or blood pressure. And yet, those who fall outside
the so-called normal range are commonly advised that losing
or gaining weight will improve their health. When we apply a standard of normal
to all of humanity that’s based on data 
from a non-representative slice, we’re not just choosing one
point on the distribution, we’re choosing it 
from the wrong distribution. A lot of behavior science research draws
from samples that are pretty WEIRD— meaning Western, educated, 
industrialized, rich, and democratic. These features can skew norms even in research that doesn’t have
an obvious link to them. Take the famed 
Muller-Lyer optical illusion: it’s normal to think one 
of the two lines is longer, when they’re actually the same length. At least, it is if you’re
an American undergraduate. A team of anthropologists 
and psychologists found other demographic groups
were much less susceptible— members of the San people of the Kalahari weren’t susceptible 
to the illusion at all. When these limited or inaccurate
definitions of normal are used to make decisions 
that impact people’s lives, they can do real harm. Historically, such concepts of normal
have been hugely influential. The Eugenics Movement of the early 20th 
century weaponized the concept of normal, using it to justify exclusion, violence, 
and even extermination of those deemed not normal. To this day, people are often targeted
and discriminated against on the basis of disabilities, 
mental health issues, sexual orientations, gender identities, and other features
deemed “not normal.” But the reality is that the differences
in our bodies, minds, perceptions, and ideas about
the world around us— in short, diversity— 
is the true normal.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In 1945, two sculptures, meant to represent the average man and woman in the United States, went on exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History. Based on measurements taken from tens of thousands of young men and women, what were they called?
Options: A. Norma and Normman, B. Norma and Norman, C. Nora and Norbert, D. Mr. and Mrs. Right
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the purpose of creating the sculptures Norma and Normman in 1945? Options: A. To represent the average man and woman in the United States based on measurements taken from tens of thousands of young men and women., B. To promote the concept of normalcy in society., C. To showcase the diversity of human traits., D. To study the effects of normalcy on mental health. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the outcome of the contest launched to find a living embodiment of Norma? Options: A. Many women matched Norma's description., B. A few women matched Norma's description., C. Not one of almost 4,000 women matched Norma's description., D. The contest was cancelled due to lack of participants. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What does a normal distribution in statistics describe? Options: A. A set of values that fall along a straight line., B. A set of values that fall along a bell curve., C. A set of values that fall along a random pattern., D. A single data point. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the limitation of using BMI as a measure of health? Options: A. It takes into account body fat percentage, body fat distribution, levels of physical activity, and blood pressure., B. It only measures weight relative to height., C. It is only applicable to certain age groups., D. It is only applicable to certain ethnic groups. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What does the term WEIRD refer to in the context of behavior science research? Options: A. Western, educated, industrialized, rich, and democratic., B. Western, educated, intelligent, rational, and diverse., C. Worldly, educated, innovative, rational, and democratic., D. Weird, eccentric, irrational, and dysfunctional. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the finding of the study on the Muller-Lyer optical illusion? Options: A. All demographic groups were equally susceptible to the illusion., B. Only American undergraduates were susceptible to the illusion., C. Members of the San people of the Kalahari were more susceptible to the illusion., D. Members of the San people of the Kalahari were not susceptible to the illusion. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the potential harm of using limited or inaccurate definitions of normal? Options: A. They can lead to greater understanding and acceptance of diversity., B. They can do real harm and impact people's lives negatively., C. They can lead to greater conformity and social cohesion., D. They can have no impact on people's lives. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the consequence of the Eugenics Movement's use of the concept of normal? Options: A. It led to greater acceptance and inclusion of people with disabilities., B. It led to exclusion, violence, and even extermination of those deemed not normal., C. It had no impact on society., D. It led to greater understanding and acceptance of diversity. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the reality of human diversity according to the transcript? Options: A. Human diversity is abnormal and should be eliminated., B. Human diversity is the true normal and should be celebrated., C. Human diversity is irrelevant and has no impact on society., D. Human diversity is a threat to social cohesion. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the implication of the transcript's discussion on normalcy? Options: A. We should strive to be normal and conform to societal norms., B. We should reject the concept of normalcy and celebrate diversity., C. We should use the concept of normalcy to make decisions that impact people's lives., D. We should ignore the concept of normalcy and its implications. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the question content and options, the most similar generated MCQ is not present in the list. But if I had to choose one that is somewhat related, I would say Question 1 is the closest.

However, I must note that Question 1 does not ask about the names of the sculptures, but rather their purpose. Therefore, it does not closely match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to provide an index, I would say Question 1 (Index 1) is the closest, but it's not a good match.

A better-generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ would be:

Question: What were the names of the two sculptures meant to represent the average man and woman in the United States that went on exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History in 1945?
Options: A. Norma and Normman, B. Norma and Norman, C. Nora and Norbert, D. Mr. and Mrs. Right

This question is not present in the list of generated MCQs.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1945, two sculptures meant to represent
the average man and woman in the United States went on exhibit
at the American Museum of Natural History. Based on measurements taken from tens
of thousands of young men and women, they were called Norma and Normman. That same year, a contest launched
to find a living embodiment of Norma. Normal is often used as a synonym
for “typical,” “expected,” or even “correct.” By that logic, most people should fit 
the description of normal. And yet, not one of almost 4,000 women 
who participated in the contest matched Norma,
the supposedly “normal” woman. This puzzle isn’t unique 
to Norma and Normman, either— time and time again, 
so-called normal descriptions of our bodies, minds, and perceptions 
have turned out to match almost no one. And yet, a lot of the world is constructed
around a foundation of normalcy. So what does normal actually mean—
and should we be relying on it so much? In statistics, a normal distribution 
describes  a set of values that fall along a bell curve. The average, or mean, of all the values
is at the very center, and most other values fall 
within the hump of the bell. These curves can be tall, with most values
inside a narrow range, or long and flat, with only a slight bias
towards the average. What makes the distribution normal 
is that it follows this curved shape. Normal doesn’t describe a single data 
point, but a pattern of diversity. Many human traits, like height,
follow a normal distribution. Some people are very tall or very short, but most people fall close 
to the overall average. Outside of statistics, normal
often refers to an average— like the single number pulled 
from the fattest part of the bell curve— that eliminates all the nuance
of the normal distribution. Norma and Norman’s proportions
came from such averages. Applied to individuals, 
whether someone is considered normal usually depends on how closely 
they hew to this average. At best, such definitions of normal 
fail to capture variation. But oftentimes, our calculations of normal
are even more flawed. Take the BMI— or Body Mass Index. BMI is a measure of weight
relative to height, with different ratios 
falling into “underweight,” “normal weight,” “overweight,”
and “obese” ranges. Generally, only BMIs that correspond
to normal weight are considered healthy. But BMI is not always 
an accurate predictor of health, or even of what’s a healthy weight. BMI doesn’t take into account 
body fat percentage, body fat distribution, levels of physical
activity, or blood pressure. And yet, those who fall outside
the so-called normal range are commonly advised that losing
or gaining weight will improve their health. When we apply a standard of normal
